[[S&P 500|S&P 500 Component]] | founder = | area_served = | key_people = [[David P. King]] ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | industry = [[Health care]] | products = | services = [[Medical laboratory|Clinical laboratory]] | revenue = {{ubl|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 8,505.7 million (2015) {{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/920148/000092014816000162/lh10-k2015.htm#s952FD10CCF2255D39B4B55A2344C12FE|title=LABORATORY CORP OF AMERICA HOLDINGS 2015 Annual Report Form (10-K) |publisher=United States Securities and Exchange Commission |format=XBRL |date=February 29, 2016}}}}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 6,011.6 million (2014) }}}} | operating_income = {{ubl|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 1,002.9 million (2015) }}|{{nowrap|{{decrease}} US$ 910.4 million (2014) }}}} | net_income = {{ubl|{{nowrap|{{decrease}} US$ 436.9 million (2015) }}|{{nowrap|{{decrease}} US$ 511.2 million (2014) }}}} | assets = {{ubl|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 14,221.7 million (2015) }}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 7,301.8 million (2014) }}}} | equity = {{ubl|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 4,944.4 million (2015) }}|{{nowrap|{{increase}} US$ 2,820.5 million (2014) }}}} | owner = | num_employees = 60,000 | num_employees_year = 2017 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | foundation = {{start date and age|1978|9|5}} (as Roche BioMedical) | location_city = [[Burlington, North Carolina|Burlington]], [[North Carolina]], U.S. | location_country = | location = | locations = | homepage = [http://www.labcorp.com/ www.labcorp.com] }} '''Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings''', more commonly known as '''LabCorp''', is an American [[S&P 500]] company headquartered in [[Burlington, North Carolina|Burlington]], [[North Carolina]]. It operates one of the largest clinical laboratory networks in the world, with a United States network of 36 primary laboratories. Before a merger with National Health Laboratory in 1995, the company operated under the name '''Roche BioMedical'''. LabCorp performs its largest volume of specialty testing at its Center for Esoteric Testing in Burlington, North Carolina, where the company is headquartered.[http://stocks.us.reuters.com/stocks/fullDescription.asp?symbol=LH&WTmodLOC=L2-LeftNav-8.5-FullDescription Full Description, Laboratory Corporation of America Hldg LH (NYSE)], reuters.com[http://www.secinfo.com/ds2yr.4f8a4.d.htm Laboratory Corp of America Holdings · 8-K], SECInfo.com, Filed On 12/4/01, SEC File 1-11353, Accession Number 920148-1-500043 As of 2018, LabCorp processes 2.5 million lab tests weekly.{{cite news |title=FBI Aware Of 'Reports Of Ransomware Attack' Involving LabCorp Security Breach |url=https://www.wfmynews2.com/article/news/fbi-aware-of-reports-of-ransomware-attack-involving-labcorp-security-breach/83-574887499 |work=WFMY}} LabCorp was an early pioneer of [[genomic]] testing using [[polymerase chain reaction]] (PCR) technology, at its Center for Molecular Biology and Pathology in [[Research Triangle Park, North Carolina]], where it also performs other molecular diagnostics. It also does [[oncology]] testing, [[human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) [[genotyping]] and [[phenotyping]]. LabCorp also operates the National Genetics Institute, Inc. (NGI) in [[Los Angeles, California]] which develops PCR testing methods.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ngi.com/company/|title=Who We Are|last=|first=|date=2006|website=National Genetics Institute|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} LabCorp's ViroMed facility, originally in [[Minnetonka, Minnesota]] until closing this site in 2013,{{Cite web|url=http://tcbmag.com/News/Recent-News/2013/May/Minnetonka-Lab-Will-Lay-Off-79-Workers|title=Minnetonka Lab Will Lay Off 79 Workers|last=Anderson|first=Jake|date=2013-05-08|website=Twin Cities Business Magazine|publisher=MSP Communications, Inc.|access-date=2016-10-14}} is now housed in Burlington, NC{{Cite web|url=http://www.viromed.com/about-us|title=ViroMed Laboratories: About Us|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Viromed Laboratories|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} and performs [[Real-Time PCR|real-time PCR]] microbial testing using laboratory-developed assays. LabCorp also provides testing in [[Puerto Rico]] and, outside the United States, in three [[Provinces and territories of Canada|Canadian province]]s. LabCorp utilizes seven [[PA-31-350 Navajo Chieftain|PA-31-350]]'s and one [[PC-12]] aircraft on nightly runs from Burlington, NC for use on the East Coast. ==History== ===Revlon=== '''National Health Laboratories Incorporated''' began in 1978.[http://apps.sos.ky.gov/business/obdb/(ve2xdr3otn0fjtjicknbi33r)/showentity.aspx?id=0111772&ct=09&cs=99999 Name NATIONAL HEALTH LABORATORIES INCORPORATED, Organization Number 0111772]{{dead link|date=February 2012}}, Kentucky Secretary of State, Business Services, File Date 9/5/1978 The company was a national blood and [[pathology]] laboratory owned by the [[Revlon Health Care Group]], and managed by [[Michael E. Lillig]] for seven years. Lillig had earlier been with [[Becton, Dickinson and Company]]. At National Health Laboratories, Inc. he grew annual sales of the company each year by 43%, with revenue reaching $12 million by the end of his tenure. Lillig then left to found several health-care companies, including [[Syscor]], Inc., Intelysis, Inc., [[Asterion]], LLC and [[MetaCyte]]'s [[3DR Laboratories|3DR]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].[http://3drinc.net/lillig.html Michael E. Lillig, Managing Director, Co-Founder & Board Member], 3DR, 2003 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009203339/http://3drinc.net/lillig.html |date=October 9, 2007 }} ===National Health Laboratories, Inc.=== In 1988, National Health Laboratories became publicly traded on the [[NASDAQ]] exchange.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/832427/0000832427-94-000010.txt|title=Form 10-K - Item 1. DESCRIPTION OF BUSINESS|last=|first=|date=1994-03-25|website=[[EDGAR]]|publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]|access-date=2016-10-14|ref=Form10K_1994}} [[Revlon]] retained 24% ownership of the common shares, for the next six years.Standard & Poors's Stock Guide, various issues Revlon had been a publicly traded company since the 1950s, as it was during most of its ownership of National Health Laboratories. But in 1985, Revlon had been taken over by [[Ronald Perelman]]. Through early 1995, the National Health Laboratories principal executive offices were located at 4225 Executive Square, Suite 805 in [[La Jolla, California]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20070926235856/http://www.shareholder.com/lh/EdgarDetail.cfm?CompanyID=LH&CIK=920148&FID=950157-94-81&SID=94-00 NATIONAL HEALTH LABORATORIES HOLDINGS INC., SEC FORM 8-B], Shareholder.com, March 8, 1994 In 1989, the company generated revenue of about US$400 million, with about US$70 million in earnings.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9405E7D6163AF934A25754C0A966958260 National Health Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30], New York Times Archives, Published: July 17, 1990 In 1990, the company's revenues reached US$500 million, with over US$70 million in earnings. That year, the company began paying a cash [[dividend]] to shareholders. In 1991, National Health Laboratories moved from the NASDAQ OTC exchange to the [[New York Stock Exchange]], where it began to trade under the new ticker symbol NH. Up until that time the company had performed very well, including through the [[1990-1991 recession]]. Its earnings peaked that year at almost US$90 million, and its stock price had risen from its low within the prior few years by several-fold. However, beginning in 1991 the company became embroiled in Operation "[[Labscam]]," a nationwide crackdown on fraud in the health-care system, initiated by the U.S. Attorney's Office in [[San Diego, California]]. The charges were that the company and others routinely submitted false claims to the government health-care agencies [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] and [[Medicaid]] for unnecessary tests which physicians had never ordered. In 1992, National Health Laboratories became the first of the companies to be prosecuted in the government operation.[http://www.uow.edu.au/arts/sts/bmartin/dissent/documents/health/labscam.html OPERATION LABSCAM, LabCorp of America, SmithKline Beecham and Corning, Inc (now Quest Diagnostics)], compiled by Michael Wynne, August 2003 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812010348/http://www.uow.edu.au/arts/sts/bmartin/dissent/documents/health/labscam.html |date=August 12, 2007 }} In 1992, the company reported revenues of over US$720 million, however with earnings of only US$40 million. The small gain that year reflected a fourth quarter charge of US$80 million, which the company paid in a settlement agreement with state and federal governments related to the LABSCAM investigation.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=980CE2DB1639F93BA35751C0A962958260 National Health Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31], New York Times Archives, Published: February 8, 1994 The total payments made by National Health Laboratories in the settlement came to US$111 million that year, [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=health&res=9D0DE2DC1738F936A25751C1A962958260 COMPANY NEWS; Blood-Testing Concerns Plan $1.79 Billion Merger], New York Times, By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Published: December 15, 1994 and ultimately reached US$173 million. In 1993, revenues were up to US$761 million, with new peak earnings of nearly US$113 million. By that time the company had 22 major laboratories.{{cite web | url =http://edgar.secdatabase.com/356/95015794000192/filing-main.htm | title = National Health Laboratories 1994 Current Report - Form 8-K - July 08, 1994. | publisher = secdatabase.com | accessdate = 2012-05-17}} The stock price reached a new all-time high in 1993, which became the peak for the next couple of years, and the company was added to the S&P MidCap 400 list. ===National Health Laboratories Holdings=== On March 8, 1994 National Health Laboratories Inc. reorganized as a holding company, '''National Health Laboratories Holdings Inc.''' By 1994, [[MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings]] Inc. then owned the Revlon Holdings Group's former 24 percent of National Health Laboratories Holdings. That company was a distributor of [[licorice]] extract and chocolate, which had previously been taken over, along with Revlon, by [[Ronald Perelman]] in the 1980s. On May 4, 1994, National Health Laboratories announced that it would acquire [[Allied Clinical Laboratories]], Inc. of [[Nashville, Tennessee]], reducing their takeover offer to $204 million after federal officials issued new subpoenas in an investigation of Medicare billing practices at Allied Clinical Laboratories Inc.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/09/business/company-news-bid-for-allied-clinical-is-cut-after-investigation-widens.html|title=COMPANY NEWS; Bid for Allied Clinical Is Cut After Investigation Widens|last=Adelson|first=Andrea|date=1994-06-09|website=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} In 1993, Allied generated revenues of US$163 million. The former President and CEO of Allied Clinical, [[Haywood D. Cochrane, Jr.]], then became Vice Chairman of National Health Laboratories. In order to complete the cash transaction, the company discontinued paying its dividend at that time.[http://www.secinfo.com/dPct4.b1.b.htm National Health Laboratories Inc · 10-Q · For 3/31/94], SECInfo.com, Filed On 5/10/94, SEC File 1-10740, Accession Number 832427-94-14 By the end of 1994, the company had run into financial difficulty again, as it struggled through the economic [[soft landing (economics)|soft landing]] that year. Its earnings dropped by over two-thirds, to only US$30 million. The stock never traded that year at more than half of its 1993 peak, and at its 1994 low, it was down by nearly two-thirds from the all-time high. ===Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings=== On April 28, 1995 National Health Laboratories Holdings Inc. merged with [[Hoffmann-La Roche|Roche]] Biomedical Laboratories, Inc. and changed its name to '''Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings'''. It began trading under its new ticker symbol LH.[http://www.secinfo.com/ds2yr.a4.htm Laboratory Corp of America Holdings · 10-Q · For 3/31/95], SECInfo.com, Filed On 5/15/95, SEC File 1-11353, Accession Number 920148-95-11 Shareholders of National Health Laboratories received 0.72 shares of the new company, plus $5.60 in cash, for a 50.1 percent interest in the new company. At the time, [[James R. Maher]] was President and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of National Health Laboratories. Following the merger, Maher relinquished those positions, and instead became Chairman of the new company, succeeding the financier Ronald O. Perelman in that position. Perelman received about US$100 million from the deal, which made the new company the largest blood-testing company in the United States. The merged company created revenues of US$1.7 billion. National Health Laboratories already held long-term debt of US$351 million. Together with the Roche debt, the combined companies owed US$590 million prior to the merger. Another US$288 million was added to help finance the payout to shareholders. By year-end 1995, the new company's total debt reached US$959 million. Roche Biomedical Laboratories had been created by and was a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Hoffmann-La Roche]], Inc., the American arm of the Swiss medical conglomerate, [[Roche Holding, Limited]]. Before 1982, the core of Roche Biomedical Laboratories had been [[Biomedical Reference Laboratories]], which dated from the late 1960s, and was located in Burlington, North Carolina. That core company had become publicly traded in 1979. Hoffman-La Roche acquired it for US$163.5 million in 1982 and then merged it with all of its laboratories, and incorporated the merged company that year as Roche Biomedical Laboratories, Inc. in Burlington. By the early 1990s, Roche Biomedical had become one of the largest clinical laboratory networks in the United States, with US$600 million in sales.[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Roche-Biomedical-Laboratories-Inc-Company-History.html Roche Biomedical Laboratories, Inc.], FundingUniverse.com By 1993 Roche Biomedical Laboratories had revenues of US$712 million, with 17 major laboratories. Dr. [[James Powell (biologist)|James Powell]] was President of Roche Biomedical, and after the merger with National Health Laboratories he became President and CEO of the new company, Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings, which then relocated from La Jolla, California to the Roche Biomedical headquarters in Burlington, North Carolina. Hoffmann-La Roche also contributed US$186.7 million in cash to the deal, and retained 49.9 interest in the new merged company. By year-end 1995, the new Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings suffered a marginal loss of a few million dollars. The stock price dropped by almost half again through the year, to within 10% of its all-time low since going public a half dozen years earlier. By early the next year, it broke marginally below that level, and set a new all-time low. In July 1998, LabCorp acquired the Michigan-based laboratory division of ''Universal Standard Healthcare'' (UHCI). LabCorp also acquired an equity position in Universal Standard Healthcare and has become UHCI's clinical laboratory long-term testing provider{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/labcorp-completes-acquisition-of-universal-standard-healthcares-michigan-based-laboratory-division-76081052.html|title=Labcorp Completes Acquisition Of Universal Standard Healthcare's Michigan-Based Laboratory Division|last=|first=|date=1998-08-05|website=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} but terminated this agreement one year later.{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/labcorpr-ends-agreement-with-universal-standard-healthcare-of-michigan-inc-75536407.html|title=LabCorp(R) Ends Agreement with Universal Standard Healthcare of Michigan, Inc.|last=|first=|date=1999-03-30|website=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In June 2000, LabCorp completed the acquisition of [[San Diego]]-based ''Pathology Medical Laboratories'' for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/labcorp-completes-acquisition-of-pathology-medical-laboratories-in-california-73716467.html|title=LabCorp Completes Acquisition of Pathology Medical Laboratories in California|last=|first=|date=2000-06-27|website=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In 2000, LabCorp generated revenues of US$1.9 billion with over 18,000 employees. In May 2001, LabCorp completed its acquisition of ''Path Lab Holdings Inc.'', the largest regional laboratory in [[New England]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/stories/2001/04/30/daily11.html|title=LabCorp completes acquisition of Path Lab|last=|first=|date=2001-05-01|website=[[Triad Business Journal]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} and just a few weeks later the acquisition of [[Minneapolis]]-based ''ViroMed Inc.'', specialized on clinical diagnostic testing in [[virology]], [[molecular biology]], [[serology]], [[microbiology]], [[mycology]] and mycobacteriology, as well as in tissue/eye bank testing, for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/labcorpr-acquires-viromed-inc-72019757.html|title=LabCorp(R) Acquires ViroMed Inc.|last=|first=|date=2001-06-04|website=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In December 2001, LabCorp became the exclusive marketer for genomics and [[proteomics]] predictive cancer test products made by [[Myriad Genetics]], Inc.{{Cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/877869/Myriad-Genetics-LabCorp-form-a-marketing-alliance.html|title=Myriad Genetics, LabCorp form a marketing alliance|last=|first=|date=2001-12-04|website=[[Deseret News]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} In May 2002, LabCorp announced the acquisition of all outstanding Shares of Canadian medical laboratory services company [[Dynacare|Dynacare Inc.]] for $480 million in cash and own shares.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/dynacare-accepts-offer-from-labcorp/article1023077/|title=Dynacare accepts offer from LabCorp|last=|first=|date=2002-05-10|website=[[The Globe and Mail]]|publisher=Phillip Crawley|access-date=2016-10-14}} In January 2003, LabCorp acquired all of the outstanding shares of ''Dianon'', a provider of [[anatomical pathology]] and [[oncology]] testing]] services,{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/labcorpr-completes-acquisition-of-dianon-systems-inc-73902777.html|title=LabCorp(R) Completes Acquisition of DIANON Systems Inc.|last=|first=|date=2003-01-17|website=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} for $598 million in cash.{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB1037025698768572108|title=LabCorp Agrees to Buy Dianon for $598 Million|last=|first=|date=2002-11-11|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In 2005, LabCorp's revenues totaled $3.3 billion; in 2006, revenues were $3.6 billion; and in 2007, revenues reached $4.1 billion.[[Wikinvest:Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings|LH 2007 10-K, pg. 8 via Wikinvest]] In March 2005, LabCorp announced the acquisition of all outstanding Shares of ''Esoterix, Inc.'', a leading provider of specialty reference testing, for approximately $150 million in cash from private equity firm ''Behrman Capital''.{{Cite web|url=https://scrip.pharmamedtechbi.com/deals/200510076|title=LabCorp acquires Esoterix for $150mm|last=|first=|date=April 2005|website=Script Pharma Intelligence|publisher=[[Informa PLC]]|access-date=2016-10-14}} In November 2006, LabCorp acquired ''Litholink Corporation'', a [[Kidney stone disease|kidney stone]] analysis laboratory. In December 2007, LabCorp acquired ''Tandem Labs'', a [[Contract research organization]] specializing in advanced [[mass spectrometry]], immunoanalytical support, [[pharmacokinetics]], and [[pharmacodynamics]], headquartered in [[Salt Lake City, UT]] for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20080124005889/en/LabCorp-Announces-Definitive-Agreement-Acquire-Tandem-Labs|title=LabCorp Announces Definitive Agreement to Acquire Tandem Labs, Inc.|last=|first=|date=2008-01-24|website=[[Business Wire]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway]]|access-date=2016-10-14}} In June 2009, LabCorp acquired [[Monogram Biosciences]], a diagnostic lab specializing in HIV resistance testing, headquartered in [[South San Francisco, California|South San Francisco, CA]], in a cash tender of $4.55 per share for approximately $155 million including debt.{{cite web|url=http://www.zacks.com/stock/news/21373/Monogram+Acquired+by+LabCorp|title=Monogram Acquired by LabCorp|date=23 June 2009|publisher=Zacks Investment Research|accessdate=23 December 2009}} In May 2010, LabCorp acquired the assets of its [[Santa Ana, California]]-based rival ''Westcliff Medical Laboratory'' which had just filed a [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11]] bankruptcy action in federal court.{{Cite web|url=http://www.darkdaily.com/westcliff-medical-laboratories-files-bankruptcy-will-be-sold-to-labcorp-524|title=Westcliff Medical Laboratories Files Bankruptcy, Will Be Sold to LabCorp|last=|first=|date=2010-05-24|website=Dark Daily|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} The FTC challenged this acquisition{{Cite web|url=https://www.ftc.gov/news-events/press-releases/2010/12/ftc-challenges-labcorps-acquisition-rival-clinical-laboratory|title=FTC Challenges LabCorp's Acquisition of Rival Clinical Laboratory Testing Company|last=|first=|date=2010-12-01|website=[[Federal Trade Commission]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} but lost in court.{{Cite web|url=https://www.skadden.com/insights/california-district-court-denies-federal-trade-commission-request-preliminary-injunction-me|title=California District Court Denies Federal Trade Commission Request for a Preliminary Injunction in Medical Laboratory Merger Case|last=Aronson|first=Clifford H.|last2=Stoll|first2=Neal R.|date=2011-03-03|website=[[Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In September 2010, LabCorp announced the acquisition of ''Genzyme Genetics'', formerly a division of [[Genzyme Corporation|Genzyme]], with 9 testing laboratories and approximately 1900 employees, for $925 million in cash.{{Cite web|url=https://www.genomeweb.com/dxpgx/labcorp-buy-genzyme-genetics-925m|title=LabCorp to Buy Genzyme Genetics for $925M|last=|first=|date=2010-09-13|website=GenomeWeb|publisher=Genomeweb LLC|access-date=2016-10-14}} In June 2011, LabCorp acquired their Canadian central labs partner ''Clearstone'' from investment firm ''Czura Thornton'' for an undisclosed amount, thus adding Clearstone's global network of central laboratories, including sites in China, France, Singapore and Canada, and the central laboratory protocol management system APOLLO CLPM to their portfolio.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pharmatimes.com/news/labcorp_to_acquire_central_labs_partner_clearstone_980944|title=LabCorp to acquire central labs partner Clearstone|last=Mansell|first=Peter|date=2011-06-02|website=PharmaTimes|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} In November 2011, LabCorp completed the acquisition of more than 90% of the shares of DNA testing company ''Orchid Cellmark'' for $85 million but had to sell parts of Orchid's [[DNA paternity testing|paternity business]] to ''DNA Diagnostics Center''.{{Cite web|url=http://medcitynews.com/2011/12/labcorp-completes-85m-acquisition-of-orchid-cellmark/|title=LabCorp completes $85M acquisition of Orchid Cellmark|last=Vinluan|first=Frank|date=2011-12-16|website=MedCity News|publisher=Breaking Media, Inc.|access-date=2016-10-14}} In May 2012, LabCorp Clinical Trials sold its European biological sampling kit building operation located in [[Hamburg]] to clinical [[Supply chain management|supply chain]] solutions provider ''Marken''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/marken-acquires-european-kit-building-operation-from-labcorp-clinical-trials-150016105.html|title=Marken Acquires European Kit Building Operation From LabCorp Clinical Trials|last=|first=|date=2012-05-03|website=[[PR Newswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In August 2012, LabCorp completed the acquisition of rival testing lab ''Medtox Scientific'' for $241 million.{{Cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/labcorp-insists-it-s-doing-the-buying-for-now/81247122|title=LabCorp Insists It's Doing the Buying For Now|last=|first=|date=2012-08-01|website=[[Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News]]|publisher=[[Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.]]|access-date=2016-10-14}} In September 2013, LabCorp acquired ''MuirLab'', the clinical laboratory [[outreach]] business from [[John Muir Health]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.johnmuirhealth.com/about-john-muir-health/press-room/Press-releases/2013-09-04-john-muir-health-sells-clinical-laboratory-outreach-services-to-labcorp.html|title=John Muir Health Sells Clinical Laboratory Outreach Services to LabCorp|last=|first=|date=2013-09-04|website=[[John Muir Health]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-15}} In October 2014, LabCorp announced it had entered into an agreement to acquire [[Covance Inc.]] for approximately $6.1 billion.{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-03/labcorp-to-buy-covance-for-6-1-billion-to-add-drug-r-d.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Phil | last=Serafino | title=LabCorp to Buy Covance for $6.1 Billion to Add Drug R&D | date=November 3, 2014}} Just a few weeks later, LabCorp completed its $85.3 million acquisition of ''LipoScience'', a developer of diagnostic tests based on [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy|nuclear magnetic resonance technology]] measuring heart disease risk.{{Cite web|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2014/10/15/673519/10102823/en/LabCorp-s-Acquisition-of-LipoScience-Clears-Antitrust-Approval.html|title=LabCorp's Acquisition of LipoScience Clears Antitrust Approval|last=|first=|date=2014-10-15|website=[[GlobeNewswire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} In December 2014, LabCorp announced the completion of its acquisition of ''Bode Technology Group, Inc.'', a provider of [[Forensic science|forensic]] DNA analysis, [[DNA collection]] products, and relationship testing, ''from SolutionPoint International, Inc.'' for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite web|url=http://www.forensicmag.com/news/2014/12/labcorp-announces-acquisition-bode-technology|title=LabCorp Announces Acquisition of Bode Technology|last=|first=|date=2014-12-09|website=[[Forensic Magazine]]|publisher=Advantage Business Media|access-date=2016-10-14}} In October 2015, LabCorp announced the acquisition of ''Safe Foods International Holdings, LLC'' and its two operating companies, ''International Food Network'' and ''The National Food Laboratory'' for an undisclosed amount, thus expanding their capabilities in food and beverage product-development and product-integrity.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20151023005057/en/LabCorp-Acquires-Safe-Foods-International-Holdings|title=LabCorp Acquires Safe Foods International Holdings|last=|first=|date=2015-10-23|website=[[Business Wire]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} In March 2016, LabCorp completed the acquisition of [[Torrance, California|Torrance, CA]]-based laboratory firm ''Pathology Inc.'', a provider of expertise in reproductive FDA donor testing as well as anatomic, molecular and digital pathology services, for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite web|url=https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/211709/labcorp-expands-in-womens-health-acquires-pathology-inc|title=LabCorp Expands in Women's Health, Acquires Pathology, Inc|last=|first=|date=2016-03-29|website=zacks.com|publisher=Zacks Investment Research|access-date=2016-10-14}} In August 2016, LabCorp announced it would acquire [[Sequenom]] for $371 million including debt, thus expanding its reach overseas, especially in Europe and Asia.{{Cite web|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/labcorp-to-acquire-sequenom-for-371m/81253008/|title=LabCorp to Acquire Sequenom for $371M|last=|first=|date=2016-07-27|website=[[Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News]]|publisher=[[Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.]]|access-date=2016-10-14}} In October 2016, LabCorp acquired ''ClearPath Diagnostics'', a provider of laboratory diagnostic services in the Northeastern United States, from private equity firm ''Shore Capital Partners'' for an undisclosed amount.{{Cite web|url=https://www.genomeweb.com/business-news/labcorp-acquires-clearpath-diagnostics|title=LabCorp Acquires ClearPath Diagnostics|last=|first=|date=2016-10-05|website=GenomeWeb|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} In May 2017, LabCorp acquired the Pathology Associates Medical Laboratories in Spokane, WA from Providence Health & Services and Catholic Health Initiatives for an undisclosed sum.{{Cite news|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2017/may/04/labcorp-completes-purchase-of-spokanes-paml|title=LabCorp completes purchase of Spokane’s PAML|date=2017-05-04|work=The Spokesman-Review|access-date=2018-03-05}} In July 2017, LabCorp acquired the contract research organisation (CRO) ''Chiltern'' for $1.2 Billion.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-chiltern-m-a-laboratory-corp-idUSKBN1AG13R|title=LabCorp to expand oncology offerings with $1.2 billion Chiltern buy|date=2017-07-31|work=Reuters|access-date=2017-07-31}} ===Acquisition history=== The following is an illustration of the company's major mergers and acquisitions and historical predecessors (this (Acq 2017) }}}}}} === Incidents === LabCorp has been criticized for its practice of paying the salaries of genetic counselors in hospitals and doctors' offices, which is perceived to be a possible conflict of interest.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/14/business/conflict-potential-seen-in-genetic-counselors-paid-by-testing-companies.html?pagewanted=all|title=Conflict Potential Seen in Genetic Counselors|last=Pollack|first=Andrew|date=13 July 2012|work=|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=|via=}} In July 2018, LabCorp was hit with a [[ransomware]] attack.{{cite web |last1=Copeland |first1=Rob |last2=Evans |first2=Melanie |title=Medical Testing Giant LabCorp Hit by Ransomware Attack |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/medical-testing-giant-labcorp-hit-by-ransomware-attack-1532001600 |website=Wall Street Journal |date=19 July 2018}}{{cite web |title=FBI Aware Of 'Reports Of Ransomware Attack' Involving LabCorp Security Breach |url=https://www.wfmynews2.com/article/news/fbi-aware-of-reports-of-ransomware-attack-involving-labcorp-security-breach/83-574887499 |website=WFMY}} == Corporate governance == {{As of|2013|December}}, the LabCorp Board of Directors includes Garheng Kong.{{Cite news|title = People|date = December 2013|page = 53|type = paper|volume = 33|issue = 21|work = [[Gen. News]]}} In 1997 Roche owned 49.7% of LabCorp but sold all of their LabCorp stock until 2002.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/triad/stories/2002/03/04/daily37.html|title=Roche to sell LabCorp shares at $86.50 each|last=|first=|date=2002-03-07|website=[[Triad Business Journal]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-14}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.labcorp.com/ LabCorp website] {{Finance links | name = LabCorp | symbol = LH | sec_cik = LH | yahoo = LH | google = LH }} * [http://jobs.labcorp.com/ LabCorp Careers] *[[Wikinvest:Laboratory Corporation of America Holdings|LabCorp Profile at Wikinvest]] {{North and South Carolina Corporations}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Labcorp}} [[Category:Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Health care companies established in 1978]] [[Category:Health care companies based in North Carolina]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]]

[[File:Lazarus Angbazo.jpg|thumb|Lazarus Angbazo]] '''Lazarus Angbazo''' (born 1962) is a [[Nigerian]]-[[United States|American]] [[engineer]] and business leader. He is the President and [[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive Officer]] of [[General Electric]] in Nigeria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://build.export.gov/build/idcplg?IdcService=DOWNLOAD_PUBLIC_FILE&RevisionSelectionMethod=Latest&dDocName=eg_us_ga_077619|title=GE Nigeria Lazarus Angbazo is the President and CEO of GE Nigeria|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Before assuming his role in Nigeria where he has doubled the GE revenue in the country by over $1billion, he led GE’s regional operations between 2008 and 2012 as President & CEO, West, East & Central Africa. He is also the President of the [https://www.abcnig.com/ American Business Council] in Nigeria.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thescoopng.com/2015/07/28/american-business-council-appoints-lazarus-angbazo-as-new-president/|title=American Business Council appoints Lazarus Angbazo as new president|last=|first=|date=July 28, 2015|website=TheScoopNG|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He is also the President of GE Energy Connection Africa.
== Early life & education == Lazarus Angbazo was born in Keffi, [[Nasarawa State]] of Nigeria into the royal family of Angbazo. He is a native of Eggon, from Awayi community of Wakama Development area of Nasarawa Eggon, Nasarawa State, Nigeria. His father, His Royal Highness (Dr.) Bala A. Angbazo is the Aren Eggon, the traditional ruler of the Eggon people and his mother Mrs. Polina Angbazo was the queen.
He attended Government College Keffi. He obtained his Bachelors Degree from the Ahmadu Bello University Zaria with a First Class Honors Degree in Mathematics in 1982. From there he studied Industrial Engineering and Operations Research for his Masters' Degree at the [[University of Iowa]] before taking a PhD in Corporate Finance at the [[New York University]].
== Career ==
=== General Electric === Angbazo joined GE from [[JPMorgan Chase|JP Morgan Chase & Co]] in 2004 where he was the Vice President, Corporate Treasury and Development. He started off as the Managing Director and Chief Marketing Officer of GE Commercial & Industrial Finance. He became the MD, Industry Client Coverage Team at GE Capital in 2006 before he was redeployed to head the West, East and Central Africa operations as the pioneer GE executive in the region. In 2012, Angbazo became the Chief Executive of GE business operations in Nigeria where he doubled revenues to over $1 billion. He was responsible for facilitating GE investment of $1 billion for the creation of a multi-modal manufacturing and service hub for Africa including a service plant for power turbines in Calabar, Cross River state.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://venturesafrica.com/nigeria-ge-flags-off-1-billion-manufacturing-facility/|title=NIGERIA: GENERAL ELECTRIC FLAGS OFF $1 BILLION MANUFACTURING FACILITY|last=|first=|date=June 19, 2013|website=Ventures Africa|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ge-plant-nigeria-idUSKCN18E26S|title=General Electric to launch service plant for power turbines in Nigeria|last=Oludare|first=Mayowa|date=May 18, 2017|website=Reuters|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Rail Concession ==== General Electric signed an interim concession agreement with the Federal Government of Nigeria for the operation of Nigeria's narrow-gauge railway system. The consortium deal which was led by GE Nigeria CEO, Angbazo was worth $45million for the interim jphase of the project and $2.9billion for the entire phase of the project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://saharareporters.com/2018/04/30/ge-led-consortium-signs-agreement-nigeria-rail-concession|title=GE Led Consortium Signs Agreement With Nigeria For Rail Concession|last=|first=|date=April 30, 2018|website=Sahara Reporters|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Employment ==== Angbazo tripled GE employment in Nigeria from about 200 to 500 employees within 3 years with about ninety percent of Nigerian National employees occupying eighty percent of leadership positions in the organisation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gfmag.com/topics/africa/ge-all-paths-lead-africa|title=Will Africa Deliver Growth For GE?|last=|first=|date=January 4, 2018|website=Global Finance|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> General Electric Nigeria was also ranked by job matching portal, Jobberman as the best Nigerian company to work for in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jobberman.com/blog/jobberman-best-100-companies-work-nigeria-2016/|title=Jobberman Best 100 Companies to Work For in Nigeria 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=Jobberman|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Academic and Public Sector === Angbazo was an Assistant Professor of Finance at the Purdue University, Indiana between September 1992 to May 1997. During this time, he took a sabbatical leave for one year and joined the Fannie Mae, as Director-Housing Finance Research from 1995 to 1996. He has authored several research articles in corporate finance and capital markets published in ''Journal of Fixed Income'', ''Journal of Banking and Finance, European Finance Review, Journal of Risk and Insurance,'' and ''Management Science Journal.'' He is a speaker at the Krannert Executive Forum at [[Krannert School of Management]], Purdue University.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://krannert.purdue.edu/events/exec-forum/speakers/02%202018-fall/02%20-%20September%2007.php|title=KRANNERT EXECUTIVE FORUM - LAZARUS ANGBAZO|last=|first=|date=|website=Purdue University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Board memberships ==== Angbazo currently sits on the boards of several universities and business schools in Nigeria including the [[Lagos Business School]] of the Pan-Atlantic University, the [[Africa-America Institute]] and [[Bingham University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lbs.edu.ng/advisory_board|title=LBS Advisory Board|last=|first=|date=|website=Lagos Business School|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Presidential appointment === Angbazo was appointed as a member of the Nigeria Industrial Policy and Competitiveness Advisory Council inaugurated by the chairman, Nigeria's Vice President Professor [[Yemi Osinbajo]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2017/05/31/osinbajo-inaugurates-industrial-policy-and-competitiveness-advisory-council/|title=Osinbajo Inaugurates Industrial Policy and Competitiveness Advisory Council|last=|first=|date=May 31, 2017|website=ThisDay Newspaper|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Other businessmen on the council include Africa's richest man, [[Aliko Dangote]] who is its vice-chair. The council is expected to spearhead Nigeria's industrial agenda to raise the contribution of manufacturing to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
== Personal life == He is married to Joyce Lin and they have two children; Saraya, a daughter and Jonathan, a son. They live in [[Abuja]].
== References == <references />

The '''Leadership Foundation for Higher Education''' (LFHE) is an organisation in the [[United Kingdom]] providing support and advice on leadership, governance and management for [[higher education]], based in [[Holborn]], [[London]].
==History== It was established in 2004 by the [[UUK]] and [[GuildHE|SCOP]] (now known as Guild HE). It took over the function of the Higher Education Staff Development Agency (HESDA), based in Ingram House in [[Sheffield]]. It was incorporated as a company in October 2003, and registered as a charity in February 2004.
==Structure== It is situated in Holborn off the Grays Inn Road, near [[Chancery Lane tube station]]. It is funded by the four higher education funding bodies of the UK Higher Education Funding Council for England, HEFCE; Scottish Funding Council, SFC; Higher Education Funding Council for Wales, HEFCW; and the Department for Employment and Learning Northern Ireland, DELNI.
The Leadership Foundation is a membership organisation and in 2014-15 there are 152 universities and higher education colleges in membership.
==Function== The Leadership Foundation delivers it work through programmes and events; institutional advice and consultancy and providing research on leadership, management and governance for higher education institutions. It cooperates with a wide range of organisations and associations to do this.
==Notable people== * [[Fiona Ross (nurse)|Fiona Ross]], Director of Research<ref>{{cite web|title=Professor Fiona Ross CBE|url=https://www.qni.org.uk/people/professor-fiona-ross-cbe/|website=The Queen's Nursing Institute|accessdate=26 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Higher Education Academy]] * [[National College for School Leadership]] - similar organisation for schools
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.lfhe.ac.uk Official website]

{{refimprove|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox exchange |name = London Metal Exchange |logo = |image = [[File:LME entrance sign.jpg|200px|London Metal Exchange]] |type = [[Commodities exchange]] |city = [[London]], {{postcode|EC|3}} |country = [[United Kingdom]] |founded = {{Start date and age|1877|df=yes}} |owner = [[Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing]]
(LME Holdings Limited) |key_people = |currency = [[United States dollar]] |listings = |volume = 159.7 million lots; 3.7 billion tonnes; $14.5 trillion (2012)[http://www.lme.com/who.asp About the LME] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526102107/http://www.lme.com/who.asp |date=2010-05-26 }} |indexes = |homepage = {{URL|www.lme.com}} }} The '''London Metal Exchange''' ('''LME''') is the futures exchange with the world's largest market in options and [[futures contract]]s on [[base metal|base]] and other [[metal]]s. As the LME offers contracts with daily expiry dates of up to three months from trade date, weekly contracts to six months, and monthly contracts up to 123 months,{{cite web |title=Futures Contract Specifications |url=https://www.lme.com/en-gb/metals/non-ferrous/aluminium/contract-specifications/futures/ |publisher = London Metal Exchange |accessdate=7 August 2015}} it also allows for cash trading. It offers [[Hedge (finance)|hedging]], worldwide reference pricing, and the option of physical delivery to settle contracts. Since 2012 it has been owned by [[Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing]], after LME's shareholders voted in July 2012 to approve the sale of the exchange for a price of £1.4 billion. ==History== The London Metal Market and Exchange Company was founded in 1877, but the market traces its origins back to 1571 and the opening of the [[Royal Exchange, London]]. Before the exchange was created, business was conducted by traders in London [[coffee house]]s using a makeshift ring drawn in chalk on the floor.BBC Radio 4 ''[[Today (BBC Radio 4)|Today]]'', broadcast 25 October 2011. At first only [[copper]] was traded. [[Lead]] and [[zinc]] were soon added but only gained official trading status in 1920. The exchange was closed during [[World War II]] and did not re-open until 1954.{{cite web|first=Richard|last=Northedge|title=130 years of the LME|year=2007|publisher=Newsdesk Communications|url=http://www.henrybath.com/assets/_files/documents/apr_11/HENRYBATH__1303997757_LME_130_Supplement.pdf|work=LME 130th Anniversary Supplement|accessdate=31 October 2014|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031150533/http://www.henrybath.com/assets/_files/documents/apr_11/HENRYBATH__1303997757_LME_130_Supplement.pdf|archive-date=31 October 2014}} The range of metals traded was extended to include [[aluminium]] (1978), [[nickel]] (1979), [[tin]] (1989), aluminium alloy (1992), [[steel]] (2008), and minor metals [[cobalt]] and [[molybdenum]] (2010). The exchange ceased trading [[plastics]] in 2011. The total value of the trade is around $US 11.6 trillion annually.{{cite web |title=LME achieves another year of record volume |url=http://lme.com/6935.asp |date=5 January 2009 |publisher=London Metal Exchange |accessdate=29 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401031016/http://www.lme.com/6935.asp |archivedate=1 April 2009 |df= }} Many deals are made for commodities to be delivered in three months' time. The custom stems from the time that copper cargoes originally took in 1877 on their voyage from the ports of [[Chile]]. The LME was owned by its members until 2012, when it was sold to Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing for £1.4 billion.{{cite web| first=Henry |last=Sanderson |title=London Metal Exchange debates its future |url=https://www.ft.com/video/157a944e-caaf-3f3d-90a8-e7487d1a8e7f |publisher=Financial Times| | date=24 March 2017 |accessdate=8 June 2017}} ==Commodities traded== The LME offers futures and options contracts for aluminium, aluminium alloy, NASAAC (North American Special Aluminium Alloy), cobalt, copper, lead, molybdenum, nickel, steel billet, steel rebar, steel scrap, tin and zinc. ==Facilities== [[File:LME Entrance.jpg|thumb|Main entrance to the former premises of the LME, at 56 [[Leadenhall Street]] in the [[City of London]]]] To trade contracts in copper, tin, or any other metal listed on the LME, one has to trade through an LME member. Purchasers of contracts, which are then left to reach maturity, will receive a warrant for a specific LME approved warehouse to take delivery of the metal if required. The LME issues, each day, detailed figures on how many tonnes of each metal is in its warehouses, which helps producers and consumers make correct business decisions. ==Ring trading== Trading Times: 11:40 — 17:00, London Time [[Open-outcry]] is the oldest way of trading on the exchange, though nowadays the majority of trades are placed electronically.{{cite web |title=LME Select |url=https://www.lme.com/trading/venues-and-systems/systems/lmeselect/ |publisher = London Metal Exchange |accessdate=7 August 2015}} It is central to the process of [[price discovery]], the way LME official prices are established. Prices are derived from the most liquid periods of trading; the short open-outcry ring trading sessions, and are most representative of industry [[supply and demand]]. The official settlement price, on which contracts are settled, is determined by the last offer price before the bell is sounded to mark the end of the official ring. There is constant inter-office trading. A relatively small yet important portion of trading is still done by open-outcry in the Ring. There are a morning and an afternoon trade, where each of the nine metal contracts are traded in two blocks with a five-minute session for each contract (the sessions last from 11.40 until 13.10 and from 14.55 until 16.15, each session includes a 10-minute break). The second trading block in the morning is key to setting the Daily Official Exchange rates. After the official trades of sessions one and two, there are 85 and 45 minutes of "kerb" trading respectively. Trades are in futures, options and TAPOs (traded average-price options, a form of [[Asian options]]). Whilst the price discovery mechanism used by the exchange is post-trade transparent it is not pre-trade transparent. Pre-trade transparency is required for many securities under the Market in Financial Instruments Directive (MiFiD) to achieve fair markets by reducing such illegal abuse as market manipulation. The LME is the last exchange in Europe where open-outcry trading takes place. ==Ring Dealing Members== Ring Dealing Members are entitled to trade in the Ring during the ring-trading sessions.{{cite web |title=Category 1 – Ring Dealing |url=http://lme.com/membership_ringdealing.asp |publisher=London Metal Exchange |accessdate=29 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322061843/http://www.lme.com/membership_ringdealing.asp |archivedate=22 March 2009 |df= }} They may also operate a 24-hour market by trading inter-office. All Ring Dealing Members, as members of the LME Clear, are authorised under the [[Financial Services and Markets Act 2000]], and are regulated by the [[Financial Conduct Authority]]. Ring Dealing Members are [[Clearing (finance)|Clearing]] Members, who hold the exclusive right to trade in the ring;{{cite web |title=Ring Dealing Members |url=https://www.lme.com/trading/membership/category-1-ring-dealing/ |publisher = London Metal Exchange |accessdate=7 August 2015}} *Amalgamated Metal Trading Ltd *E D & F Man Capital Markets Limited *Marex Financial Ltd *Metdist Trading Ltd *[[INTL FCStone]] Europe Ltd *GF Financial Markets (UK) Ltd *Societe Generale International Ltd *[[Sucden]] Financial Ltd *Triland Metals Ltd In addition to the 9 companies that have exclusive rights to trade in the Ring, around 100 companies are involved in the LME in total. ==Precious metals== Contrary to popular belief, the precious metals, [[gold]] and [[silver]], are not traded on the London Metal Exchange, but on the [[over-the-counter (finance)|over-the-counter]] market usually referred to as the [[London bullion market|London Bullion Market]], by the members of the [[London Bullion Market Association]]. [[Platinum]] and [[palladium]] are traded on the [[London Platinum and Palladium Market]]. Both members of the LBMA and LPPM trade the precious metals spot market on [[Electronic Broking Services|EBS]] (Electronic Broking Systems)—acquired by [[ICAP (company)|ICAP]] in June 2006. Many companies involved in minor metals are members of the [[Minor Metal Trade Association]]. The LME used,https://www.lme.com/~/media/Files/Notices/2014/2014_09/14%20269%20A261%20Precious%20Metals%20Price%20Data%20and%20Matching%20and%20Clearing%20Services.pdf however, to provide trade matching and clearing services to the London bullion market and distributes gold, silver, and gold IRS ([[interest rate swap]]s) forward rates on behalf of the LBMA. ==Electronic trading== The LME launched an electronic platform called LME Select launched in February 2001.[5] This was developed by a [[Sweden|Swedish]] software house called [http://www.cinnober.com Cinnober]. The platform is a FIX-based trading platform, and now handles a majority of the total LME business. ==Delivery points== As a market of “last resort”, industry can use the LME’s delivery option to sell excess stock in times of oversupply and as a source of material in times of extreme shortage. In reality, physical delivery occurs in a very small percentage of cases on the LME as most organizations use the LME for hedging purposes. The small percentage which does result in delivery, however, plays a vital role in creating price convergence. ==Warehouses== To support this mechanism, the LME approves and licenses a network of warehouses and storage facilities around the world. Controversy arose in 2013 because the LME took action to limit the use of its warehouses for the hoarding of aluminium. In March 2014, England's [[High Court]] found for [[Rusal]], the Russian aluminium company, striking down these rules. ==See also== *[[List of futures exchanges]] *[[London Platinum and Palladium Market]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.lme.com London Metal Exchange] {{Economy of the United Kingdom}} {{Coord|51|31|16|N|0|5|15|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} [[Category:Commodity exchanges in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organisations based in the City of London]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the City of London]] [[Category:Futures exchanges]] [[Category:1877 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1877]] [[Category:Metal industry]]

{{Infobox person |name =Mauricio Banchieri Carter |image = |birth_place = Santiago de Chile, Chile |nationality = Chilean |alma_mater = [[Universidad Nacional Andrés Bello]] |occupation = Businessman, entrepreneur, Chilean Trade Commissioner to New York at ProChile |organization = Puro Chile<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.specialtyfood.com/news/news-center/article/puro-chile/ |title=Puro Chile |author=Dennis Marrero |date=1 July 2010 |publisher=Specialty Foods |access-date=28 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160215020740/https://www.specialtyfood.com/news/news-center/article/puro-chile/ |archivedate=15 February 2016 |df= }}</ref> |website = {{url| http://www.puro-chile.com}} }} '''Mauricio Banchieri''' is a Chilean businessman and entrepreneur. Banchieri is the Chilean Trade Commissioner to New York at ProChile. He is a board member for the Chilean American Chamber of Commerce (CACC) in New York. He is the founder of Puro Chile, a [[Chile]]an specialty food store chain.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/country-specific-stores-the-next-best-thing-to-buying-there-1405090420?KEYWORDS=puro+wine |title=Country-Specific Stores: The Next Best Thing to Buying There |author=Sarah Gold |date=11 July 2014 |publisher=Wall Street Journal |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="chile.gov">{{cite web |url=http://chile.gob.cl/estados-unidos/asuntos-comerciales/oficina-comercial/ |title=Commercial Affairs Trade Office |publisher=Embassy of Chile in the United States of America| access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="Newswk">{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/retail-diplomacy-exploring-world-through-shopping-63425 |title=Retail Diplomacy: Exploring the World through Shopping |author=Amy Finnerty |date=10 December 2012 |publisher=Newsweek |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="NYT">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/30/dining/30chile.html?_r=2& |title=In SoHo, a Visit to Chile |author=Florence Fabricant |date=29 September 2009 |publisher=New York Times |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="NACCC"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jec.cl/articulos/?p=9895 |title=Con emprendedores e innovadores: el caso de la firma de tecnología móvil MZZO y Casa Check |date=18 July 2010 |publisher=El Mercurio |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Banchieri was born in [[Santiago, Chile]]. He holds a bachelor's degree in Business Administration from [[Andrés Bello National University]] in Santiago and a Master of Science in Information Systems from [[American University]] in Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.alumniunab.cl/mauricio-banchieri-carter/ |title=Mauricio Banchieri Carter |publisher=Universidad Andrés Bello |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref>
==Career== In 2004, Banchieri and his business partner founded the mobile marketing firm MZZO in Chile. MZZO was established as an [[information technology]] company, specializing in mobile marketing, web and engineering design.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.economiaynegocios.cl/noticias/noticias.asp?id=75853 |title=La faceta empresarial menos conocida de Hernán Somerville |author=Azucena González |date=18 July 2010 |publisher=Economía y Negocios |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref>
According to Newsweek, in 2009 Banchieri founded Puro Chile, a store to promote "the best products and services Chile has to offer to the city of New York."<ref name="Newswk"/> Puro Chile and Puro Vino are niche shopping stores that promote Chilean culture in New York through luxury goods, food, textiles, and wine.<ref name="WSJ"/><ref name="Newswk"/><ref name="NYT"/> The Wall Street Journal classified Puro Chile as one of the best country-specific stores in NYC.<ref name="WSJ"/>
In 2012, Banchieri was selected by the Business and Economics faculty at the Universidad Andrés Bello as the most successful alumni for his graduating year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://facultades.unab.cl/economiaynegocios/uncategorized/mauricio-banchieri-fue-el-ganador-de-la-facultad-de-economia-y-negocios-en-premios-alumni-2012/ |title=Mauricio Banchieri fue el ganador de la Facultad de Economía y Negocios en Premios Alumni 2012 |date=2012 |publisher=Economía y Negocios |access-date=28 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204233922/http://facultades.unab.cl/economiaynegocios/uncategorized/mauricio-banchieri-fue-el-ganador-de-la-facultad-de-economia-y-negocios-en-premios-alumni-2012/ |archivedate=4 February 2016 |df= }}</ref>
Banchieri is a board member of the Chilean-American Chamber of Commerce of New York.<ref name="NACCC">{{cite web |url=http://www.nacchamber.com/?board |title=Board of Directors |publisher=North American Chilean Chamber of Commerce |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref> In January 2015, he spoke on a panel discussing the economical and business climate in Latin America at a conference hosted by the CACC.<ref name="Global">{{cite web |url=http://globalphiladelphia.org/news/cacc-hosts-latin-america-2015-economic-business-and-trade-forecast |title=CACC Hosts Latin America 2015: Economic, Business and Trade Forecast |date=26 January 2015 |publisher=Global Philadelphia |access-date=28 January 2016}}</ref>
===Chilean Trade Commissioner to New York=== Banchieri was named the Chilean Trade Commissioner to New York in 2014.<ref name="Global"/> As the trade commissioner, he helps develop Chilean trade in goods and services, promotes and attracts foreign direct investment, and fosters tourism.<ref name="chile.gov"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

[[Image:MediaTechnologyMonitorLogo.jpg|frame|50px|alt=Logo of the Media Technology Monitor (MTM).|Logo ]]The '''Media Technology Monitor''' (MTM) is an annual telephone survey and research product designed to monitor Canadians' use and adoption of new and existing technologies. The first MTM questionnaire was distributed in 2005 and now consists of two annual surveys conducted in the spring and fall of each year.<ref>CRTC Communications Monitoring Report (2011) - {{cite web |url=http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/policymonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005120457/http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/PolicyMonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref>
The survey features questions that focus on current and emerging media activities and technologies such as, television across multiple platforms, radio use social media, and online audio. The results of the Media Technology Monitor are published through a series of syndicated reports and multiple short, targeted theme reports. The Media Technology Monitor reports are distributed to government agencies, broadcasters, and other media stakeholders across Canada who subscribe to the service.
The MTM is designed, implemented and analyzed by the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] (CBC/Radio-Canada).<ref>Broadcaster Magazine - http://www.broadcastermagazine.com/news/bbm-analytics-to-market-cbc-radio-canada-media-technology-monitor/1000045568/</ref> In 2011, the MTM coordinated with [[Carleton University]] in Ottawa, Ontario to provide learning materials to the Communications Department.
==History== The Media Technology Monitor has evolved from the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's]] Quality Ratings Survey (QRS) that began in 1997 to measure Canadians' use and perception of Canada's conventional and specialty television channels as well as some media technology behaviours. In 2005, the MTM was launched with a specific focus on media technology adoption and use among Canadians. In 2010, an online MTM portal ([http://www.mtm-otm.ca www.mtm-otm.ca]) was created to provide a more interactive experience for users. The portal allows users a quick and easy way to download MTM reports and trending data, as well as conduct custom analysis of the data with a proprietary data analysis tool.
MTM-OTM Video on YouTube : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oGlObksktTU&feature=youtu.be
Since then the technology has become less and less used due to the rise of the internet and the easier, quicker and cheaper way to send our surveys to users which using certain methods is also further available for free.
==Survey Methodology and Design== The Media Technology Monitor is released in the fall and spring of each year and collects a total of 12,000 responses through telephone interviews with 6,000 Anglophones and 6,000 Francophones aged 18+. The response rate for both surveys is 30%.<ref>Official MTM Website - {{cite web |url=http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref>
* Fall Survey - 8,000 Respondents (4,000 Anglophones and 4,000 Francophones)<ref>Official MTM Website - {{cite web |url=http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref> * Spring Survey - 4,000 Respondents (2,000 Anglophones and 2,000 Francophones)<ref>Official MTM Website - {{cite web |url=http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.mtm-otm.ca/quest.asp |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref>
MTM survey households are selected by [[Random digit dialing|Random Digit Dialing]] (RDD) and the respondent within each household is randomly selected based on the most recent birthday method. The MTM uses telephone surveys to ensure that the respondents are representative of all Canadians by eliminating bias due to geographic location and connection to the Internet.
==Current Topics==
The Media Technology Monitor is revised every year to include emerging media trends and technologies. Recent MTM surveys have asked respondents about their behavior and consumption of:
* Conventional TV Use<ref>Globe and Mail - https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/tech-news/bye-bye-analog-hello-bidding-war-for-digital-airwaves/article2147741/</ref><ref>Playback Online - http://playbackonline.ca/2011/06/06/one-in-10-canadians-have-tried-netflix-mtm-study/</ref><ref>Genius Marketing - {{cite web |url=http://www.geniusmarketinginc.com/?p=835 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329110546/http://www.geniusmarketinginc.com/?p=835 |archivedate=2012-03-29 |df= }}</ref> ** PVRs / DVRs ** VOD ** Video streaming ** Market share of TV service providers ** Service provider * Personal Audio<ref>Mediacaster Magazine - http://www.mediacastermagazine.com/news/the-media-that-matters-most-hdtv-podcasts-mp3s/1000093251/</ref> ** Satellite radio ** Streaming radio ** Podcasts ** Traditional AM/FM radio use ** Subscription radio ** Online music downloads * Internet Usage ** Home Internet usage ** Connection speed ** Internet connected television *High Definition Television<ref>TVB - http://www.tvb.ca/pages/BBM_MediaTechnologyTrends_htm</ref> ** Number of HD TV sets ** HD Receivers ** Portable Media ** Tablets, Laptops, MP3 Players ** Audio/video content ** Consumption frequency and location * Wireless ** Smartphone usage ** Apps *Social Media ** Social networking behaviours
==Results Featured in Published Works==
* Digital Radio in Canada: From DAB to Multi-Platform Approaches, Brian O'Neill, [[Dublin Institute of Technology]], 2007<ref>Digital Radio in Canada: From DAB to Multi-Platform Approaches - http://arrow.dit.ie/aaschmedcon/9/</ref> * Broadcasting Policy in Canada, Robert Armstrong, [[University of Toronto]], 2010<ref>Broadcasting Policy in Canada - https://books.google.com/books?id=v8uRPaM_VoAC&lpg=PP1&dq=Canadian%20Media&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=true dia-2011-09-09.doc</ref> * CRTC Communications Monitoring Report, [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]], 2011<ref>CRTC Communications Monitoring Report (2011) - {{cite web |url=http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/policymonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005120457/http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/publications/reports/PolicyMonitoring/2011/cmr2011.pdf |archivedate=2011-10-05 |df= }}</ref> * [https://books.google.com/books?id=vjuJiRkx33oC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Political+Economies+of+Media:+The+Transformation+of+The+Global+Media++Industries&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false The Political Economies of Media: The Transformation of the Global Media Industries], Dwayne Winseck & Dal Jong Jin, 2011<ref>The Political Economies of Media: The Transformation of the Global Media Industries, Google Books - https://books.google.com/books?id=vjuJiRkx33oC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Political+Economies+of+Media:+The+Transformation+of+The+Global+Media++Industries&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref>

'''Media context studies''' refers to the group of studies investigating “how and which media context variables influence the effects of the [[advertisements]] embedded in the context“.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bronner|first=A.E.|author2=Neijen, P.C.|title=Audience experiences of media context and embedded advertising: A comparison of eight media|journal=International Journal of Market Research|year=2006|volume=48|pages=81–100}}</ref> Media researchers found that media context affects ad recall,<ref>{{cite journal|last=De Pelsmacker|first=P.|author2=Geuens, M. |author3=Anckaert, P. |title=Media context and advertising effectiveness: The role of context appreciation and context/ad similarity|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2002|volume=31|issue=2|pages=49–61|doi=10.1080/00913367.2002.10673666}}</ref> ad recognition,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Moorman|first=M.|author2=Neijens, P. C. |author3=Smit, E. G. |title=The effects of magazine-induced psychological responses and thematic congruence on memory and attitude toward the ad in a real-life setting|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2002|volume=31|issue=4|pages=27–40|doi=10.1080/00913367.2002.10673683}}</ref> level and nature of ad processing,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Shapiro|first=S|author2=MacInnis, D.J.|title=Understanding program-induced mood effects: Decoupling arousal from valence|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2002|volume=31|issue=4|pages=15–26|doi=10.1080/00913367.2002.10673682}}</ref> ad attitude and ad cognitions,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Coulter|first=K.S.|title=The effects of affective responses to media context on advertising evaluations.|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=1998|volume=27|issue=4|pages=41–51|doi=10.1080/00913367.1998.10673568}}</ref> brand attitude,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lord|first=K.R.|author2=Burnkrant, R. E. |author3=Unnava, H. R. |title=The effects of program-induced mood states on memory for commercial information|journal=Journal of Current Issues & Research in Advertising|year=2001|volume=23|issue=1|pages=1–15|doi=10.1080/10641734.2001.10505110}}</ref> and purchase intention.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Yi|first=Y|title=Cognitive and affective priming effects of the context for print advertisements.|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=1990|volume=19|issue=2|pages=40–48|doi=10.1080/00913367.1990.10673186}}</ref>
Media context would influence media users’ attitude toward ads in several ways. First, the similarity in the mood of the media context and the ads would enhance learning and evaluations of the ad and its message.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Coulter|first=K.S.|title=The effects of affective responses to media context on advertising evaluations.|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=1998|volume=27|issue=4|pages=41–51|doi=10.1080/00913367.1998.10673568}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=De Pelsmacker|first=P.|author2=Geuens, M. |author3=Anckaert, P. |title=Media context and advertising effectiveness: The role of context appreciation and context/ad similarity|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2002|volume=31|issue=2|pages=49–61|doi=10.1080/00913367.2002.10673666}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Lord|first=K.R.|author2=Burnkrant, R. E. |author3=Unnava, H. R. |title=The effects of program-induced mood states on memory for commercial information|journal=Journal of Current Issues & Research in Advertising|year=2001|volume=23|issue=1|pages=1–15|doi=10.1080/10641734.2001.10505110}}</ref> Goldberg and Gorn (1987)<ref>{{cite journal|last=Goldberg|first=M.E.|author2=Gorn, G. J.|title=Happy and sad TV programs: How they affect reactions to commercials|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|year=1987}}</ref> call this the mood congruency-accessibility hypothesis: The ad context makes a certain mood or affect more accessible and relieves the processing of stimuli with similar moods or affects. Second, the prestige of the media source would rub off on the brand and influence the perceptions of the advertised brand. Fuchs (1964) <ref>{{cite journal|last=Fuchs|first=D. A.|title=Two source effects in magazine advertising|journal=Journal of Marketing Research|year=1964|volume=1|issue=3|pages=59–62|doi=10.2307/3150058|jstor=3150058}}</ref> found support for this hypothesis and he called it the congruity principle: the medium and the advertised brand converge and become more similar in consumers’ minds. Third, the media context can serve as a cognitive prime that guides the attention and determines the users’ interpretation of the ads.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dahlén|first=M.|title=The medium as a contextual cue: Effects of creative media choice|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2005|volume=34|issue=3|pages=89–98|doi=10.1080/00913367.2005.10639197}}</ref> For instance, a print ad promoting a large car may be interpreted as safe when the context is an [[editorial]] article about safety, or as fuel-thirsty when the context is an editorial article about oil.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Yi|first=Y|title=Cognitive and affective priming effects of the context for print advertisements.|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=1990|volume=19|issue=2|pages=40–48|doi=10.1080/00913367.1990.10673186}}</ref> Forth, the nature of the medium itself may moderate the editorial content’s influence on acceptance of the ads. For example, ads in print media can be skipped more easily compared to ads on radio and television, so the appreciation of the magazine editorial may lead to less ad processing than on radio and television.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Norris|first=C.E.|author2=Colman, A. M.|title=Context effects on recall and recognition of magazine advertisements|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=1992|pages=37–46|jstor=4188844|volume=21|issue=3|doi=10.1080/00913367.1992.10673374|hdl=2381/3970}}</ref>
While the influence of media context on embedded ads undoubtedly exists and is important, it is complicated and difficult to evaluate. The related theories may be conflicting in this regard. For example, the Feelings-as-information Theory suggested that people in a positive mood tend to avoid stimuli such as ads.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kuykendall|first=D.|author2=Keating, J. P.|title=Mood and persuasion: Evidence for the differential influence of positive and negative states.|journal=Psychology & Marketing|year=1990|volume=7|issue=1|pages=1–9|doi=10.1002/mar.4220070102}}</ref> If people acquire a good mood as a result of processing media content, they may avoid paying attention to ads embedded in this context and process them less intensively. However, the Hedonic Contingency view stated that people in a positive mood may engage in greater processing of a stimulus because they believe that the consequences are going to be favorable.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lee|first=A.Y.|author2=Sternthal, B.|title=The effects of positive mood on memory|journal=Journal of Consumer Research|year=1999|volume=26|issue=2|pages=115–127|doi=10.1086/209554}}</ref> Given the complexity of the issue, a framework of media context effect on advertising response is demanded. One such endeavor is conceptualizing media engagement as an antecedent of the attitude toward the embedded advertisements.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Calder|first=B. J. |author2=Malthouse,E.C. |author3=Schaedel, U.|title=An experimental study of the relationship between online engagement and advertising effectiveness|journal=Journal of Interactive Marketing|volume=23|issue=4|pages=321–331|doi=10.1016/j.intmar.2009.07.002|year=2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Dahlén|first=M|title=The medium as a contextual cue: Effects of creative media choice.|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2005|volume=34|issue=3|pages=89–98|doi=10.1080/00913367.2005.10639197}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bronner|first=A.E.|author2=Neijens, P. C.|title=Audience experiences of media context and embedded advertising: A comparison of eight media|journal=International Journal of Market Research|year=2006|volume=48|pages=81–100}}</ref>
This approach attempts to connect U&G perspective to studies media context effects on users’ attitude toward ads. Researchers conceptualized different attributes of individual media users as media engagement and posited that it serves as an antecedent of the attitude toward the embedded advertisements.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Calder|first=B. J. |author2=Malthouse,E.C. |author3=Schaedel, U.|title=An experimental study of the relationship between online engagement and advertising effectiveness|journal=Journal of Interactive Marketing|volume=23|issue=4|pages=321–331|doi=10.1016/j.intmar.2009.07.002|year=2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Dahlén|first=M|title=The medium as a contextual cue: Effects of creative media choice.|journal=Journal of Advertising|year=2005|volume=34|issue=3|pages=89–98|doi=10.1080/00913367.2005.10639197}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bronner|first=A.E.|author2=Neijens, P. C.|title=Audience experiences of media context and embedded advertising: A comparison of eight media|journal=International Journal of Market Research|year=2006|volume=48|pages=81–100}}</ref> Initially, scholars used the term experience to refer to these influential factors when relating to how media use would influence advertisement acceptance. Experience was described as “an emotional, intuitive perception that people have while using the media” <ref>{{cite journal|last=Calder|first=B. J.|author2=Malthouse, E. C. |author3=Schaedel, U. |title=An experimental study of the relationship between online engagement and advertising effectiveness|journal=Journal of Interactive Marketing|year=2009|volume=23|issue=4|pages=321–331|doi=10.1016/j.intmar.2009.07.002}}</ref> (p. 84). Calder and Malthouse (2009)<ref>{{cite journal|last=Calder|first=B. J.|author2=Malthouse, E. C. |author3=Schaedel, U. |title=An experimental study of the relationship between online engagement and advertising effectiveness|journal=Journal of Interactive Marketing|year=2009|volume=23|issue=4|pages=321–331|doi=10.1016/j.intmar.2009.07.002}}</ref> defined media experience as “the thoughts and feelings consumers have about what is happening when they are doing something” in or with media (p. 257). For example, users have a utilitarian experience when they believe a website provides information that facilitates their decision making. They have an intrinsically enjoyable experience when other content enables them to escape from the pressures of daily life. Calder and Malthouse (2009) described experience as consisting of two dimensions: the hedonic value associated with the experience and the motivational component, which is posited as engagement. Hence, the engagement is conceptualized as “the sum of the motivational experiences consumers have with the media product” (p. 259), which affects the strength of media experience. It influences people’s reaction to advertisements because the strong motivational experiences consumers have with a media vehicle would make an ad potentially part of something that consumers are trying to make happen in their life.
Scholars have tested the relationship between media engagement and advertising effectiveness and suggested that all things being equal, if consumers engaging with a media vehicle have strong motivational experiences, an ad potentially becomes more effective on this medium as well. Based on this argument Calder and Malthouse (2006)<ref>{{cite journal|last=Calder|first=B.J.|author2=Malthouse, E. C.|title=Managing media and advertising change with integrated marketing|journal=Journal of Advertising Research-New York|year=2005|volume=45|issue=4|pages=356|doi=10.1017/s0021849905050427}}</ref> proposed a media congruency hypothesis and tested it empirically with magazine ads, with positive results. With the emergence of the Internet, Calder, Malthouse and Schaedel (2009) <ref>{{cite journal|last=Calder|first=B. J.|author2=Malthouse, E. C. |author3=Schaedel, U. |title=An experimental study of the relationship between online engagement and advertising effectiveness|journal=Journal of Interactive Marketing|year=2009|volume=23|issue=4|pages=321–331|doi=10.1016/j.intmar.2009.07.002}}</ref> tested it in Website context and also got supportive results. The experiment yielded a positive correlation between Web users’ engagement with Websites and reaction toward an [[Orbitz]] (an online travel agency) ad. This study showed both overall engagement and personal and social interactive engagement affected reaction to ads, while social interactive engagement was more uniquely attributed to online media having an independent effect on ad reaction.
