{{Infobox officeholder |name = Moïse Katumbi |image = WO1A8393.tif |office = Governor of [[Katanga Province]] |term_start = January 2007 |term_end = 29 September 2015 |predecessor = Ngoie Kisula |successor = Jean-Claude Kazembe Musonda |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|12|28|df=y}} |birth_place = Kashobwe, [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo-Kinshasa]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy]] {{small|(Before 2015)}}
Independent (2015–18)
Together for Change (2018–present) |spouse = Carine Katumbi{{cite journal |title=Matata III: M.Katumbi pas d'accord avec J. Kabila sur le choix d'un ministre |url=http://7sur7.cd/new/matata-iii-m-katumbi-pas-daccord-avec-j-kabila-sur-le-choix-dun-ministre/ |journal=7 sur 7 |date=28 September 2015}} }} '''Moïse Katumbi Chapwe''' ({{IPA-fr|mɔiz katœ̃bi}}; born 28 December 1964) is a Congolese politician and businessman. He was the [[Governor]] of the [[Katanga Province]], located in the southern part of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], from 2007 to September 2015. He was a member of the [[People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy]] (PPRD) until September 2015. He has been described by ''[[The Economist]]'' as "probably the second most powerful man in the Democratic Republic of Congo after the president, [[Joseph Kabila]]". ''[[Jeune Afrique]]'' named him "African of the Year" in 2015. ==Background and personal life== Moïse Katumbi was born on 28 December 1964 to a Congolese mother and a [[Greeks|Greek]] father, Nissim Soriano.{{cite news |title=Moses Katumbi. Katanga Champion |author=Collete Braeckman |url=http://www.courrierinternational.com/article/2009/05/07/katanga-big-boss |work=[[Courrier International]] |date=6 May 2009 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} Katumbi's father, a Greek [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardic Jew]], fled [[Rhodes Island]] in 1938 with his two sisters after the introduction by the Italian fascist regime of the discriminatory [[Italian Racial Laws|Racial Laws]] (Rhodes was under Italian occupation since 1912). He settled in [[Katanga Province|Katanga]], a province of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], which was a Belgian colony at the time.{{cite news |title=Katumbi: The Moses of Katanga |author=Anver Versi |url=http://africanbusinessmagazine.com/uncategorised/katumbi-the-moses-of-katanga/|work=[[African Business]]|date=4 April 2013 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} Katumbi's mother was of [[Kazembe]] royalty of Lunda People of Congo and Zambia and his grandfather was Mwata Kazembe XIV.(Chief of Lunda Kingdom){{cite book |title=Nachituti's Gift: Economy, Society, and Environment in Central Africa |author=David M. Gordon |authorlink= |year=2006 |publisher=University of Wisconsin Press |location= |isbn= |page=91 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VCPddQtZz8AC&dq=Nissim+Soriano+italy&source=gbs_navlinks_s |accessdate=15 January 2016}} The family adopted the name Katumbi from a great grandfather on his mother’s side. Katumbi grew up in the village of Kashobwe in the Congo{{cite news |title=The governor of the province of Katanga, Moïse Katumbi, escapes an attack in Kashobwe |author=Willy Kabwe |url=http://www.digitalcongo.net/article/51826 |work=Digital Congo TV|date=6 July 2008 |accessdate=25 February 2016}} near [[Lake Mweru]] near the border of [[Zambia]]. His father was involved in the fishing trade. Katumbi studied at the Kiwele school of [[Lubumbashi]] and the Kapolowe mission.{{cite news |title=Portrait of Moise Katumbi Chapwe |author=Denis Kayenge |url=http://www.enews24.com.au/portrait-de-moise-katumbi-chapwe/ |work=Enews24 |date=2014 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} He is married to Carine Katumbi.{{cite news |title=Mining firms fear civil strife in Katanga |author= |url=http://www.africaintelligence.com/AMA/exploration-production/2015/01/13/mining-firms-fear-civil-strife-in%C2%A0katanga,108056366-ART |work=African Intelligence |date=13 January 2015 |quote="The governor, whose wife Carine is increasingly influential, can also…" |accessdate=15 January 2016}} His older half-brother is Raphael Katebe Katoto, a businessman and retired politician who was a member of [[RCD-Goma]]{{cite news |title=DRC: how far will Moses Katumbi? |author=Pierre Boisselet |url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/mag/269603/politique/rd-congo-jusquou-ira-katumbi/ |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |date=8 October 2015 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} and led a political party that opposed Congolese president [[Joseph Kabila]] in 2006.{{cite news |title=Congo copperlands boss prefers business to politics |author=Katrina Manson |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/congo-democratic-copper-idUSLDE6AL1VJ20101124 |work=Reuters |date=24 November 2010 |accessdate=15 January 2016}}{{cite news |title=Soccer-Loving Congolese Businessman Eyes Run for Presidency |author=Thomas Wilson |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-11/soccer-loving-congolese-businessman-eyes-run-for-presidency |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=10 November 2015 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} Katumbi is one of the wealthiest people in the DRC.{{cite news |title=TP Mazembe Surprises the World, Not Itself |author=Jack Bell |url=http://goal.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/12/17/tp-mazembe-surprises-the-world-not-itself/?_r=0 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=17 December 2010 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} He has been the subject of two documentaries by director [[Thierry Michel]]: ''[[Katanga Business]]'' and ''The Irresistible Rise of Moïse Katumbi''.{{cite news |title=Pay channel brings Diff into your home |author=Debashine Thangevelo |url=http://www.iol.co.za/tonight/movies/pay-channel-brings-diff-into-your-home-1723022 |work=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]] |date=21 July 2014 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} == Private career == Katumbi's career began in the fishing industry when he was 13.{{cite news |title=Moïse Katumbi Chapwe: A Man the West Would Love To Do Business With |author=Paul Trustfull |url=http://www.forbescustom.com/EmergingMarketsPgs/CongoInterviewsP1.html |work=Forbes Custom |date= |accessdate=15 January 2016}} He sold salted and fresh fish to the state-owned mining company [[Gécamines]]. In 1987, he created the [[holding company]] Etablissement Katumbi to aggregate all of his business activities including [[mining]], [[transportation]], and [[food processing]]. Katumbi founded MCK (Mining Company Katanga) in 1997, which specialized in mining and [[logistics]] and [[Subcontractor|subcontracted]] for mining companies in the region, including Gécamines.{{cite news |title=Necotrans acquired an important company of Moses Katumbi |author= |url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/277951/economie/necotrans-fait-lacquisition-dune-importante-societe-de-moise-katumbi/ |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |date=9 November 2015 |accessdate=5 February 2016}}{{cite news |title=Millionaire governor gears up for 2016 Congo election bid |author=Aaron Ross |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-congodemocratic-politics-idUKKCN0QG1E020150811 |work=[[Reuters]] |date=11 August 2015 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} By 2015, the company had grown to 1900 employees and was a leading mining company in the country. French company Necotrans bought MCK in November 2015 for an undisclosed amount. Around 2000, during the [[Second Congo War]], Katumbi moved to Zambia, where he had business ties in transportation. He returned to the DRC in 2003 by invitation from President Kabila, who urged Katumbi to help fix the mining industry in Katanga.{{cite news |title=Katumbi: The Moses of Katanga |author= |url=http://africanbusinessmagazine.com/uncategorised/katumbi-the-moses-of-katanga/ |work=[[African Business]] |date=4 April 2013 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} ===Football=== Since 1997, Katumbi has been the president of the [[Association football|football]] team [[TP Mazembe]] in [[Lubumbashi]].{{cite news |title=Is Moise Katumbi eyeing DR Congo presidency? |author=Bienvenu-Marie Bakumanya |work=Ghana Web |date=18 November 2015 }} The team has won the [[CAF Champions League]] title five times, including 2009, 2010, and 2015, and became the first African team to play in the [[FIFA Club World Cup]] finals in 2010.{{cite news |title=Kings of Africa: How Moise Katumbi Redefined Congolese Football Club TP Mazembe |author=Yomi Kazeem |url=http://venturesafrica.com/kings-of-africa-how-moise-katumbi-redefined-congolese-football-club-tp-mazembe/ |work=Ventures Africa |date=11 November 2015 |accessdate=5 February 2016}}{{cite news |title=Moise Katumbi: Football team owner determined to rebuild Congo |author=Tom Hayes |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/25/moise.katumbi/index.html |work=CNN: African Voices |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} Katumbi has invested heavily in the team and been credited by the media and public as one of the reasons for the club’s success. Under his tenure, the team has recruited players from [[Zimbabwe]], [[Tanzania]], [[Ghana]], and Zambia, and retained local players by paying the highest wages for players in Africa.{{cite news |title=Investment in TP Mazembe pays dividends |author=James Melik |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-12017632 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=17 December 2010 |accessdate=5 February 2016}}{{cite news |title=TP Mazembe's dreams of another final are extinguished |author= |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/TP-Mazembe-s-dreams-of-another-final-are-extinguished-400685 |work=Ghana Web |date=14 December 2015 |accessdate=25 February 2016}} Katumbi invested $35 million in building the team a stadium which was completed in 2011.{{cite news |title=An old ally of Joseph Kabila leaves the ruling party |author= |url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21671178-joseph-kabila-may-just-have-acquired-powerful-new-rival-presidents-old-ally-leaves |work=[[The Economist]] |date=6 October 2015 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} Katumbi began a football academy in 2012 as a social program to engage and train young Congolese people in the province of Katanga.{{cite news |title=TP Mazembe owner sponsors Kotoko academy project with US$ 100,000 |author= |url=http://ghanasoccernet.com/tp-mazembe-owner-sponsors-kotoko-academy-project-with-us-100000/ |work=Ghana Soccernet |date=23 October 2012 |accessdate=1 March 2016}} In 2015, 2,000 young men were enrolled in the academy. In 2012, Katumbi was elected to the [[FIFA]] strategic commission.{{cite news |title=Moses Katumbi elected member of the Strategic Committee of FIFA|author= |url= http://www.radiookapi.net/sport/2012/01/06/moise-katumbi-elu-membre-la-commission-strategique-de-la-fifa|work=Radio Okapi |date=6 January 2012 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} In 2013, he was elected to the [[Africa Cup of Nations]] organizing committee, which he is slated to chair until 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.tpmazembe.com/en/news/7389/organizing-committee-of-afcon-the-chairman-reappointed |title=Organizing Committee of AFCON: the Chairman reappointed |author= |date=5 June 2015 |work=tpmazembe.com |publisher=[[TP Mazembe]]|accessdate=5 February 2016}} He has also served on the marketing committee of the [[Confederation of African Football]] (CAF) since 2009. ==Political career== In 2006, Katumbi was elected as a deputy in the [[National Assembly (Democratic Republic of the Congo)|National Assembly]]. He was the first [[election|democratically elected]] Governor of the Katanga Province in January 2007, receiving 94 votes out of 102. Katumbi's governance has been credited with bringing [[Economic recovery|economic revival]] to the province through developing [[infrastructure]], encouraging [[Foreign direct investment|foreign investment]] with [[tax break]]s and reduced government [[regulation|procedures]], and targeting [[Democratic Republic of the Congo#Corruption|corruption]].{{cite news |title=Kabila’s "Decoupage": An Aim at Moise Katumbi’s Rising Popularity |author=Peter Adamu |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201506101109.html |work=[[AllAfrica.com]] |date=10 June 2015 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} Through Katumbi's efforts as governor, local [[tax]]es increased from $80 million in 2007 to more than $3 billion in 2014.{{cite news |title=Moïse Katumbi: New African Leadership |author=Eva M. Clayton |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/eva-m-clayton/moise-katumbi-new-african-leadership_b_5671773.html |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=14 August 2014 |accessdate=5 February 2016}} Annual [[revenue]]s increased from 100 million in 2007 to 1.5 billion by 2013. Shortly after he took office as governor, Katumbi implemented an export ban for raw [[mineral]]s, including [[cobalt]], forcing [[List of companies based in the Democratic Republic of the Congo#Mining|major mining companies]] to either build [[Oil refinery|processing plants]] in the province or pay a tax on the exported concentrate.{{cite news |title=Province of promise: the mission of Moise Katumbi |author= |url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/articles/2008/10/15/province-of-promise-the-mission-of-moise-katumbi |work=BusinessDay |date=15 October 2008 |accessdate=5 February 2016}}{{cite news |title=Congo Raises Tax on Copper, Cobalt Concentrates by Two-Thirds |author=Michael J Kavanaugh |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-07-25/congo-raises-tax-on-copper-cobalt-concentrates-by-two-thirds |work=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]] |date=25 July 2013 |accessdate=25 February 2016}} Under Katumbi, [[copper]] production increased from 8,000 metric tons in 2006 to more than 1 million tons in 2014. Along with [[Mining industry of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|mining]], Katumbi focused on expanding other areas of the province's economy including the [[Tertiary sector of the economy|service industry]], [[Energy industry|energy]] and [[agriculture]]. He offered both free [[Agricultural land|farmland]] and tax breaks for farmers to encourage food production. Reliance on imported food decreased 68% between 2006 and 2011. In 2014, the amount of food grown locally had tripled. The accomplishments of his administration included improving travel and commerce through the building or rebuilding more than 1,500 kilometers (approximately 30%) of roads and the increase in other infrastructure, including bridges, hospitals and schools. Access to clean water rose from 3% to 67% between 2007 and 2013. Additionally, within 6 years, the number of children attending school increased from 400,000 in 2007 to 3 million in 2014. The number of girls enrolled in school tripled. Worker-focused initiatives included encouraging local mining companies to invest in growing crops for their employees and the banning of "unnecessary dismissal of employees". In September 2015, Katumbi resigned as governor and from his [[political party]], the [[People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy]].{{cite news |title=Congolese Opposition Mulls Katumbi as Presidential Candidate, |author=Thomas Wilson |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-12/congo-opposition-will-consider-katumbi-as-presidential-candidate |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=12 November 2015 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} On 22 June 2016, he was convicted, in absentia, of selling a house that was not his and sentenced to 36 months in jail. This was seen as part of President [[Joseph Kabila]]'s attempts to hold on to power.{{cite news |title=Congo’s president jails his rival |url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21701397-president-joseph-kabila-playing-it-nasty-congos-president-jails-his-rival |newspaper=[[The Economist]] |date=27 June 2016 |accessdate=6 July 2016}} On 2 January 2018, Katumbi declared his candidacy for president for the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2018|2018 DR Congo general election]].{{Cite news|url=http://information.tv5monde.com/afrique/rd-congo-moise-katumbi-un-candidat-menace-105865|title=R.D. Congo : Moïse Katumbi, un candidat menacé|date=2016-05-06|work=TV5MONDE|access-date=2018-06-11|language=fr}} The next day, his home in [[Lubumbashi]] was surrounded by police who accuse him of hiring mercenaries, which he denies. On 12 March 2018, Katumbi officially launched his presidential campaign as well as his new political alliance, ''Ensemble pour le changement'' (Together for Change).{{Cite news|url=https://www.nation.co.ke/news/africa/1066-4338854-l83kv/index.html|title=Exiled DRC opposition leader launches presidency bid|work=Daily Nation|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-UK}} On 9 May, Katumbi was accused of inciting rebellion against the Kabila.{{Cite news|url=http://fr.africanews.com/2018/05/09/rdc-moise-katumbi-nie-toute-tentative-de-creation-d-une-rebellion/|title=RDC : Moïse Katumbi nie toute tentative de création d'une rébellion {{!}} Africanews|last=AfricaNews|work=Africanews|access-date=2018-06-11|language=fr}} He was also accused of being behind the [[2018 Équateur province Democratic Republic of the Congo Ebola virus outbreak|2018 Équateur province Ebola virus outbreak]].{{Cite news|url=http://stateafrique.com/rdc-moise-katumbi-a-lorigine-de-lepidemie-debola-dans-le-nord-du-pays/|title=RDC : Moïse Katumbi à l’origine de l’épidémie d’Ebola dans le nord du pays|date=2018-05-09|work=State Afrique|access-date=2018-06-11|language=fr-FR}} On 25 May, Katumbi discussed with fellow opposition presidential candidate [[Félix Tshisekedi]] at the [[Atlantic Council]] about fielding a single opposition candidate.{{Cite news|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/congolese-opposition-leaders-join-forces#.WwZv9BNNXe0.twitter|title=Congolese Opposition Leaders Join Forces|last=Sen|first=Ashish Kumar|work=Atlantic Council|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-gb}} On 1 June, attackers burned posters of Katumbi in Lubumbushi, and attempted to attack Katumbi's residence.{{Cite news|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20180601-rdc-le-siege-parti-proche-moise-katumbi-attaque-lubumbashi|title=RDC: le siège d’un parti proche de Moïse Katumbi attaqué à Lubumbashi - RFI|work=RFI Afrique|access-date=2018-06-11|language=fr-FR}} The next day, it was revealed that the perpetrators were a mission sent by Kabila who tried to kill Katumbi's relatives.{{Cite news|url=https://vacradio.com/joseph-kabila-recrute-le-tueur-de-chebeya-pour-tuer-les-proches-de-moise-katumbi-et-detruire-leurs-biens/|title=Joseph Kabila recrute le tueur de Chebeya pour tuer les proches de Moise Katumbi et détruire leurs biens|date=2018-06-02|work=VAC RADIO|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-CA}} On 9 June, Katumbi gave his first presidential campaign speech via Skype to thousands of supporters in Kinshasa.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/06/thousands-attend-exiled-dr-congo-leader-moise-katumbi-rally-180609192348221.html|title=Thousands attend exiled DR Congo leader Moise Katumbi's rally|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-11-08}} On 13 June, Katumbi was arrested at [[Zaventem Airport]] in Brussels for allegedly traveling with a fake passport while attempting to travel to Russia to attend the opening ceremony of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.lalibre.be/actu/international/l-opposant-moise-katumbi-denonce-un-acharnement-de-kinshasa-apres-l-incident-a-zaventem-5b23982f55326301e78b8060|title=L'opposant Moïse Katumbi dénonce "un acharnement" de Kinshasa après l'incident à Zaventem|last=Libre.be|first=La|access-date=2018-11-08|language=fr}} He was later granted a temporary residence permit by the Belgian authorities. Katumbi discovered that Congolese authorities had canceled his passport while going through customs at Zaventem.{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/congo-cancels-passport-of-exiled-opposition-leader-10437308|title=Congo cancels passport of exiled opposition leader|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}} On 3 August 2018, Katumbi was blocked from entering the DR Congo via the border with Zambia.{{Cite news|url=http://ewn.co.za/2018/08/03/confusion-over-moise-katumbi-s-return-to-drc|title=Confusion over Moïse Katumbi’s return to DRC|last=Cornish|first=Jean-Jacques|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en}} Those close to him are discussing with [[MONUSCO]] about Katumbi's return to the country before the presidential filing deadline on 10 August. He was greeted by thousands of his supporters in the Zambian portion of the town of [[Kasumbalesa]], along the border with the DR Congo.{{Cite news|url=https://punchng.com/congo-opposition-leader-katumbi-denied-entry-at-land-border/|title=Congo opposition leader Katumbi denied entry at land border|work=Punch Newspapers|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}} On 4 August, it was announced that Katumbi would appear before the customs union to attempt to enter the country again.{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.cd/actualite/la-une/2018/08/04/rdc-moise-katumbi-se-presentera-aujourdhui-devant-les-services-de-la-douane.html|title=RDC: "Moïse Katumbi se présentera aujourd'hui devant les services de la douane" {{!}} Politico.cd|date=2018-08-04|work=Politico.cd|access-date=2018-11-08|language=fr-FR}} On 5 August, Katumbi's lawyer, [[Eric Dupond-Moretti]], announced that he would attempt to reach out to the [[United Nations]] concerning Katumbi's denial of entry into the DR Congo.{{Cite news|url=https://afrique.lalibre.be/22623/katumbi-se-tourne-vers-la-justice-apres-avoir-ete-empeche-de-rentrer/?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter|title=Katumbi se tourne vers la justice après avoir été empêché de rentrer — La Libre Afrique|date=2018-08-05|work=La Libre Afrique|access-date=2018-11-08|language=fr-CA}} The same day, Ensemble's secretary general Delly Sesanga announced that they would file for Katumbi to run for president even if he was not in the country.https://actualite.cd/2018/08/05/rdc-presidentielle-ensemble-pour-le-changement-annonce-quil-va-deposer-la-candidature-de-katumbi/ When the final list of retained candidate for the December 23rd election was out, his name was missing since he did not make it to return home and file for his candidature ===Views=== In [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2006|2006]] and [[Democratic Republic of the Congo general election, 2011|2011]], Katumbi supported [[Joseph Kabila]]'s campaigns to run for President of the Democratic Republic of Congo.{{Cite web|title = - Www.LiveCongo.Com - Tout le Congo en Live !!! -|url = http://www.livecongo.com/dossier.php?num=1634&style=bleu&numdos=33|website = www.livecongo.com|accessdate = 2015-09-16}} However, Katumbi publicly distanced himself from Kabila in 2015.{{cite journal |title=Powerful governor of Congo's copper-rich Katanga province resigns|url=https://news.yahoo.com/powerful-governor-congos-copper-rich-katanga-province-resigns-064722826.html|journal=News Yahoo|date = 30 September 2015}} Katumbi has been outspoken about his belief that President Kabila should follow the country's constitution and step down as president in 2016. In January 2016, Katumbi joined other high-profile Congolese figures in a coalition dubbed "Front Citoyen 2016". The entity aimed to protect the constitution and attempted to ensure that the 2016 presidential elections took place.{{cite news |title=DRC: Moses Katumbi officially announces his support to the citizen Front 2016 |author=Claire Rainfroy |url=http://www.jeuneafrique.com/290907/politique/rdc-moise-katumbi-annonce-officiellement-ralliement-front-citoyen-2016/ |work=[[Jeune Afrique]] |date=4 January 2016 |accessdate=1 February 2016}} He is against Katanga [[secession]] from Congo, which is supported by a section of the province's population. Katumbi has frequently said that he prefers his private career to politics. ==Public perception== Katumbi is generally viewed positively both in Katanga Province and nationally for both his development of the Katanga region and as president of TP Mazembe. He is known for being generous, giving money directly to those who ask and investing his own funds in social causes. The media has described Katumbi's public perception as being a "[[self-made man]]" and a "man of the people". In 2011, nearly one million people signed a petition asking Katumbi to remain governor after he said he planned to quit. In 2012 he was named one of "The 50 most influential Africans" by ''[[The Africa Report]]''.{{cite news |title=The 50 most influential Africans: Moïse Katumbi Chapwe |author= |url=http://www.theafricareport.com/Central-Africa/the-50-most-influential-africans-moise-katumbi-chapwe.html|work=[[The Africa Report]] |date=20 September 2012 |accessdate=4 February 2016}} ''[[Jeune Afrique]]'' named him "African of the Year" in 2015. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commonscatinline}} {{Current DRC governors}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Katumbi Chapwe, Moise}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Governors of Katanga Province]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo people of Greek-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Democratic Republic of the Congo businesspeople]]
