{{Infobox company | name = Union Bank (Nigeria) | logo = Union-bank-Secondary-logo-wikipedia.jpg | type = [[Public Company]] | foundation = 1917 | location = 36 Marina, [[Lagos Island]], [[Lagos]], [[Lagos State]], Nigeria | key_people = Cyril Akporuere Odu
[[Chairman]]
Emeka Emuwa
[[Managing Director|Chief Executive Officer]] | num_employees = | assets = US$4.1 billion (NGN1,381 billion) (2018) | revenue = | industry = [[Financial Services]] | products = | homepage = http://www.unionbankng.com | traded_as = [[Nigerian Stock Exchange|NSE]]:'''UBN''' }} '''Union Bank of Nigeria Plc.''', commonly known as '''Union Bank of Nigeria''', is a [[commercial bank]] in [[Nigeria]]. ==Overview== Union Bank is a large commercial bank, serving individuals, small and medium-sized companies, as well as large corporations and organizations. In July 2009, it was rated the 556th largest bank in the world and the 14th largest bank in [[Africa]]. As of Mar 31, 2018, the bank's asset base was estimated at NGN1, 381 billion (US$4.1billion). The shareholders' equity at that time was estimated at NGN286 billion (US$851 million).{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201210300247.html|title=Nigeria: Standard Chartered Group, Others Buy 65 Percent Stake in Union Bank|last=Anaro|first=Blessing|date=2012-10-30|work=Leadership (Abuja)|access-date=2017-08-29}} == History == The bank was founded in 1917 as '''Colonial Bank'''. In 1925, [[Barclays Bank]] acquired Colonial Bank, changing the bank's name to Barclays Bank (Dominion, Colonial and Overseas) or '''[[Barclays Bank (DCO)]]'''. In 1969, Barclays Bank DCO was incorporated in [[Nigeria]], as '''Barclays Bank of Nigeria Limited''', to comply with new banking laws enacted in 1968. In 1971, the shares of the bank stock were listed on the [[Nigerian Stock Exchange]]. In the same year, 8.33% of the bank’s shares were offered to Nigerians. The following year, the [[Politics of Nigeria|Federal Government of Nigeria]] acquired 51.67% ownership of the bank, leaving [[Barclays|Barclays Bank Plc.]] of [[London]] with 40% ownership. In 1979, that 40% was sold to Nigerian individuals and businesses to comply with then recently enacted banking and investment laws. The bank changed its name to '''Union Bank of Nigeria Plc''''',''' '''''to reflect its new ownership structure. In 1993, the Federal Government of Nigeria completely divested its ownership in the bank. Subsequently, Union Bank of Nigeria Plc. acquired the former ''Universal Trust Bank Plc'' and ''Broad Bank Limited''. It also absorbed its former subsidiary '' Union Merchant Bank Limited''. == Member Companies == The companies that comprise the Union Bank of Nigeria Plc include :{{Cite web|url = http://www.unionbankng.com/images/downloads/2012-UNION-BANK-ANNUAL-REPORT.pdf|title = Union Bank of Nigeria 2012 Annual Report|date = December 31, 2012|accessdate = December 27, 2014|website = |publisher = Union Bank of Nigeria|last = |first = }} ; Subsidiaries * [[Union Bank UK|Union Bank United Kingdom Plc]]. * UBN Property Company Limited ==Ownership== The shares of Union Bank of Nigeria are listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange{{Cite web|url = http://www.nse.com.ng/Issuers-section/listed-securities/company-details?isin=NGUBN0000004|title = Nigerian Stock Exchange > Issuers > Listed Securities > Company Details> Union Bank of Nigeria|date = December 23, 2014|accessdate = December 27, 2014|website = |publisher = [[Nigerian Stock Exchange]]|last = |first = }} under the ticker symbol '''''UBN'''''. As at March 2018, the owners of the shares of Union Bank of Nigeria include the following corporate entities and individuals:{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201210300247.html|title=Nigeria: Standard Chartered Group, Others Buy 65 Percent Stake in Union Bank|last=Anaro|first=Blessing|date=2012-10-30|work=Leadership (Abuja)|access-date=2017-08-29}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto" |+ Union Bank of Nigeria Stock Ownership |- ! style="width:2em;" |Rank !!Name of Owner!!Percentage Ownership |- |1||Union Global Partners Limited||65.5% |- |2||Other Investors||9.6% |- |3||[[Atlas Mara Ltd]]||24.9% |- | ||'''Total'''||'''100.00''' |- |} * '''Union Global Partners Limited''' is a [[consortium]] of financial institutions that include the following: ** Africa Capital Alliance ** African Development Corporation (ADC)** ** African Development Corporation AG and [[Atlas Mara Co-Nvest Limited]] ** Corsair Investments, L.P ** FMO - the Netherlands Development Finance Company ** PPF Holdings II Limited ** Standard Chartered Private Equity ** [[Altas Mara Ltd]] ==Branch Network== The bank maintains a vast network of interconnected branches in all [[Nigeria]]n states. It has two wholly owned bank subsidiaries; [http://www.unionbankuk.com/ Union Bank UK] in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] and UBN Property Company Limited in Nigeria.[http://www.unionbankng.com/contact.htm The Branch Network of Union Bank of Nigeria] ==Board of directors== The bank's activities are supervised by a thirteen-member board of directors, chaired by [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=229063655&privcapId=25875604&previousCapId=25875604&previousTitle=African%20Capital%20Alliance Cyril Odu]. ==Management board== The management board is led by '''Mr Emeka Emuwa''', who serves as the [[Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] of the bank. He has been at the helm of the bank since November 2012.[http://www.unionbankng.com/history1.htm Emeka Emuwa is the MD & CEO of Union Bank of Nigeria] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717163421/http://www.unionbankng.com/history1.htm |date=2011-07-17 }} ==See also== * [[Economy of Nigeria]] * [[List of banks in Nigeria]] * [[Union Bank UK]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official|http://www.unionbankng.com }} *[https://www.google.com/finance?q=Union+Bank+of+Nigeria Google Finance listing for Union Bank of Nigeria] {{Economy of Nigeria}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Union Bank Of Nigeria}} [[Category:Banks of Nigeria]] [[Category:Banks established in 1917]] [[Category:Companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Companies based in Lagos]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange]] [[Category:1917 establishments in Nigeria]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} '''Witold Szczypiński''' (born 7 February 1955 in [[Sarzyna]]) – vice-president of the Management Board of [[Grupa Azoty S.A.]], Director General (former Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnowie-Mościcach S.A.).<ref name="one">{{cite web|url=http://tarnow.grupaazoty.com/en/spolka/zarzadzanie/zarzad/5|title=Zarządzanie|publisher=tarnow.grupaazoty.com|language=English|accessdate=2016-06-30}}</ref> Completed the [[Silesian University of Technology]] at the Faculty of Production Management in the scope of industry organisation and management, specialty [[chemical industry]].<ref name="one" />
== Business career ==
He has worked for Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnów-Mościce S.A. since 1979.<ref name="one" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tarnow.naszemiasto.pl/artykul/azoty-w-tarnowie-maja-dyrektora-generalnego-zostal%20nim,2219598,art,t,id,tm.html|title=Azoty w Tarnowie mają dyrektora generalnego. Został nim Witold Szczypiński|publisher=naszemiasto.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sigma-not.pl/publikacja-70901-azoty-tarn%C3%B3w-na-poczatku-xxi-wieku-przemysl-chemiczny-2012-9.html|title=Azoty Tarnów na początku XXI wieku|publisher=simga-not.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> In 1979–1987 he worked at the positions of: production master, independent process engineer, specialist process engineer in the Synthesis Unit in contemporary Zakłady Azotowe named after [[Felix Dzerzhinsky|F. Dzierżyński]] in [[Tarnów]] (currently, Grupa Azoty S.A.). From 1987 to 1990 he was the manager of the Department of Silicon and Synthesis Unit, in 1991–1999 he worked as the manager of the Synthesis Unit.<ref name="one" /><ref name="two">{{cite web|url=http://blog.grupaazoty.com/2015/04/jak-powstaly-zaklady-w-tarnowie/|title=Jak powstały Zakłady w Tarnowie?|publisher=grupaazoty.com|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
In 1997–1999 he represented Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnów-Mościce in the Supervisory Board of the Przedsiębiorstwo Innowacyjno-Wdrożeniowe UNISIL Sp. z o.o. In 1999–2001 he performed the function of the director of Plastic Centre and from 2002 to 2007 was the director for technology and development in Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnów-Mościce S.A.<ref name="one" /><ref name="two" /> In 2007–2008 he was a Member of the Management Board of Zakłady in Tarnów.<ref name="two" /> In 2007–2008 he attended the Supervisory Board of Tarnowskie Wodociągi Sp. z o.o. In 2008 he was assigned the representative of the contemporary Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnów-Mościce S.A. in the supervisory board of the Design Office of Zakłady Azotowe “BIPROZAT” Sp. z o.o and then - PKCh Sp. z o.o. (2008–2016), ATT Polymers GmbH (2011–2013) and [[Zakłady Azotowe Kędzierzyn|Grupa Azoty ZAK SA]] (2012–2016).<ref name="one" />
In 2008 he acted as the president of the management board of Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnów-Mościce S.A.<ref name="one" /><ref name="two" /> In June 2008 he was assigned the vice-president of the management board of Grupa Azoty S.A.<ref name="one" /> Since March 2014 he has also performed the function of the General Director of the company Grupa Azoty S.A. seated in [[Tarnów]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazetakrakowska.pl/artykul/3386769,azoty-tarnow-maja-nowego-dyrektora-generalnego,id,t.html?cookie=12|title=Azoty Tarnów mają nowego dyrektora generalnego|publisher=gazetakrakowska.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> As a member of the management board, he is responsible for, e.g. the integration of the plastic production and organic syntheses and sponsoring activity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lifestyle.newseria.pl/komunikaty_pr/sport/poprzeczka_coraz_wyzej,b891192437|title=Poprzeczka coraz wyżej|publisher=lifestyle.newseria.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
In 2011–2015 he was the member of the Scientific Board of the Institute of Heavy Organic Synthesis “Blachownia” in [[Kędzierzyn-Koźle]].<ref name="one" /><ref name="SZCZYPIŃSKI WITOLD">{{cite web|url=http://www.wnp.pl/kto-jest-kim/witold-szczypinski,20.html|title=SZCZYPIŃSKI WITOLD|publisher=wnp.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> In 2013 he was assigned to the Supervisory Board of Grupa Azoty SIARKOPOL.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siarkopol.grupaazoty.com/pl/spolka/zarzadzanie/rada|title=Rada nadzorcza|publisher=siarkopol.grupaazoty.com|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
He is the head of the Supervisory Board of the Polskie Konsocjum Chemiczne Sp. z o.o.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pkch.grupaazoty.com/index.php?p=spolka&s=zarzadzanie&lang=pl|title=Zarządzanie|publisher=grupaazoty.com|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pkch.co/firma.php?g=6|title=Władze Spółki|publisher=pkch.co|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
== Academic career ==
From 2011 to 2015 he performed the function of the member of the Committee of the Chemical and Process Engineering in the [[Polish Academy of Sciences]]. In 2012–2015 he was the member of the Committee managing the strategical program of scientific research and developmental works “Advanced Technologies of Energy Generation” of the [[National Centre for Research and Development in Poland|National Centre for Research and Development]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncbir.pl/programy-strategiczne/zaawansowane-technologie-pozyskiwania-energii/komitet-sterujacy/|title=Komitet Sterujący|publisher=ncbir.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kierunekenergetyka.pl/artykul,16184,grupa-azoty-przekazala-miastu-projekt-systemu-gospodarki-odpadami-i-energetyki.html|title=Grupa Azoty: Projekt gospodarki odpadami|publisher=kierunekenergetyka.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> From 2007 to 2010 he was the head of the Management Board of the SITPChem Department in Tarnów.<ref name="SZCZYPIŃSKI WITOLD"/>
He is the author or co-author numerous specialist projects: including six under patent protection, concerning the production of [[ammonia]], [[hydrogen]], food carbon dioxide, [[polyoxymethylene]], [[polycrystalline silicon]], catylisers and [[power engineering]] infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hodorowicz.pl/aktualnosci/szczegoly/uniwersytet-jagiellonski-i-grupa-azoty/|title=UNIWERSYTET JAGIELLOŃSKI I GRUPA AZOTY|publisher=hodorowicz.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://przemchem.pl/pl/rada-programowa/|title=Rada Programowa|publisher=przemchem.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref>
== Private life ==
His father - Zbigniew Szczypiński participated in the development of plants in Tarnów in the 1960s and 1970s. of the 20th century. He performed the function of, e.g. the technical director of the factory in Tarnów-Mościce.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dziennikpolski24.pl/artykul/3409851,azoty-czyli-cale-zycie-szczypinskich,id,t.html?cookie=1|title=Azoty, czyli całe życie Szczypińskich|publisher=dziennikpolski24.pl|language=Polish|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref> He is married and has a daughter.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
* [http://tarnow.grupaazoty.com/pl/spolka/zarzadzanie/zarzad/6 Profile of Witold Szczypiński on page Grupy Azoty] * [http://www.wnp.pl/kto-jest-kim/witold-szczypinski,20.html Profile of Witolda Szczypińskiego on page WNP.pl]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Şevket Sabancı | honorific_suffix = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1936}} | birth_place = Akçakaya village, [[Kayseri Province]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = [[Istanbul]], Bodrum, [[London]] | nationality = Turkish | other_names = | citizenship = Turkey | education = [[Textile engineering]] | alma_mater = [[University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology]] | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = [[Sabancı Holding]], Esas Holding | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = [[Haci Omer Sabanci Foundation]], [[Sabancı Holding]], [[Sabanci University]], Esas Holding | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = Hayırlı Zerrin Sabanci | partner = | children = [[Emine Sabancı Kamışlı]], [[Ali Sabancı|Ali İhsan Sabancı]], Sadıka Sabancı | parents = [[Hacı Ömer Sabancı]], Sadıka Sabancı | relatives = [[İhsan Sabancı]], [[Sakıp Sabancı]], [[Hacı Sabancı]], [[Erol Sabancı]], [[Özdemir Sabancı]] | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = |net_worth = {{increase}} $7-8 billion {{small|(''[[Ekonomist (Turkey)|Ekonomist]]'' 2017)}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ekonomist.com.tr/kapak-konusu/en-zengin-100-2.html}} | module = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Şevket Sabancı''' (born 1936), a second generation member of the [[Sabancı family]], is a billionaire Turkish businessman and [[philanthropist]]. ==Biography== He was born 1936 in [[Kayseri]], [[Turkey]], as the fourth son of [[Hacı Ömer Sabancı]], a self-made wealthy trader, and Sadıka. Şevket was educated in [[textile engineering]] at the [[UMIST|University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology]] (UMIST) in [[United Kingdom|England]]. Returned home, he worked at managerial positions in a number of textile companies owned by his family. After 1980, he went abroad to represent [[Sabancı Holding]]. Currently, Şevket Sabancı is the chairman of Esas Holding, the investment vehicle of his family, which owns the largest low-cost carrier in Turkey [[Pegasus Airlines]]. Şevket Sabancı was also a founding member of the [[Sabancı Foundation]] VakSA. He is married to Hayırlı Zerrin, with whom he has two daughters Emine Kamışlı, Sadıka Sabancı, and a son [[Ali Sabancı]]. ==Family Tree== Şevket Sabancı (1936 Kayseri) married to Hayırlı Zerrin *[[Emine Sabancı Kamışlı]] (1966 Adana) married to Erhan Kamisli Fethi Sabanci Kamisli (m) (1991 London) Kerem Sabanci Kamisli (m) (1993 London) *[[Ali Sabancı|Ali İhsan Sabancı]] (1969 Adana) married (1995) [[Vuslat Doğan Sabancı]] (1971) Şevket Emrecan Sabancı (m) (London 2001) Kaan Ali Sabancı (m) (New York 2003) ==Esas Holding== {{Infobox company | name = Esas Holding A.Ş. | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Anonim Şirket]] | foundation = 2000 | founder = [[Sevket Sabanci]] | location_city = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Family Office]] | key_people = [[Sevket Sabanci]] (Chairman)
[[Emine Sabancı Kamışlı]] (Vice Chairman)
[[Ali Sabanci]] (Board Member) [[Çağatay Özdoğru]] (CEO) | homepage = [http://www.esas.com www.esas.com] }} Esas Holding, the [[family office]] of the Turkish billionaire and philanthropist [[Sevket Sabanci]], was founded in 2000, and is led by his daughter [[Emine Sabancı Kamışlı]] and son [[Ali Sabanci]]. As of 2017, total assets under management is estimated to be anywhere between $4 billion to $7 billion, making it the biggest single family office in Turkey.https://www.esas.com.tr/ Esas Holding is based in Istanbul,https://www.ft.com/content/c63368d2-fa75-11e5-b3f6-11d5706b613b Turkey with an additional office in London. Direct investments and real estate development are key operating areas of the family office. Most of its direct investments are in Turkey and is made with a private equity strategy; the firm seeks to hold majority and minority stake with controlling rights, and seeks to invest for a period of between four years and six years. Some major investments of this division include Turkey's biggest low-cost carrier [[Pegasus Airlines]], Turkey's biggest Ro Ro company Un-Ro Ro, and Turkey's biggest sports club chain Mars Athletic. In 2016 Esas sold Cinemaximum, Turkey's biggest cinema chain, to the Korean cinema operator CGV for $800 million, and its snack business Peyman to London-based PE Fund [[Bridgepoint Capital]] for $100 million.https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=23221094 Esas Properties, the real estate division of Esas Holding, builds and operates shopping malls across Turkey. Property arm of Esas is also the most international division of the group, Esas Properties owns several office buildings and shopping malls in cities such as London, New York, Frankfurt, and Aberdeen.https://www.esas.com.tr/esas-properties.html ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.sabanci.com.tr/En/popup_yonetim_sevketsabanci.asp Biography at Sabancı Holding website] * [http://www.ekonomist.com.tr/kapak-konusu/en-zengin-100-2.html] {{Sabancı family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sabanci, Sevket}} [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kayseri]] [[Category:Sabancı family|Sevket Sabanci]] [[Category:Turkish businesspeople]] [[Category:Turkish philanthropists]] [[Category:Turkish billionaires]] [[Category:Tarsus American College alumni]]
